reviewText:
What a nice surprise.  Somehow this traditional indi film escaped to the multiplexes and I had occasion to check it out.  For my taste Wes Anderson is a mixed bag when it comes to his projects.  I'm about 50/50 on the likability meter.  This is his best yet.  Co-written by Anderson and Roman Coppola, the cast contains some of the usual suspects including Bill Murray, Frances McDormand, and Jason Schwartzman.

The story, which takes place in 1965, revolves around a couple 12 year olds, both of which are seen as odd by their classmates and the adults around them.  Sam (Jared Gilman) is an orphan, seen as a troublemaker by his foster parents as well as his Scoutmaster (Edward Norton).  The girl, Suzy (Kara Hayward), likewise is a bit off-putting, has no friends and hates her parents (Murray and McDormand).  While watching a church play, Sam becomes smitten with Suzy dressed as a blackbird.  Suzy appreciates the attention and together they plot to leave their homes and go off together on a great adventure through the Rhode Island coastal wilderness.

Bruce Willis is the local island cop who is also having an affair with Suzy's mom (McDormand).  I can't say enough about the cast.  Harvey Keitel plays a tight-assed Scout troop leader and Scoutmaster Ward's boss.  Tilda Swinton plays "Social Services" which is how she refers to herself.  Bob Balaban pops up here and there as The Narrator, keeping us informed as to time, location and an approaching storm.  Schwartzman is another Scout leader at another camp who agrees to help the young lovers for a bag of nickels.  Every character is wonderful and every actor delivers exacting performances.

Having said that, much of the credit must go to first time film actors Gilman and Hayward.  Played with a straight face, their budding love feels right for their age.  Some of the best scenes are when Scout Sam (he says he has now resigned and is an ex-Scout) leads Suzy through the rocky hills and woods.  Suzy travels in a short "go go" style dress with high socks, a yellow suitcase and a battery operated record player.  You can't help but laugh.  And wait `til you see the Scout's attempt at a tree house.  I'm still laughing.  A must see.

Please also check out Roger Ebert's review--he gets it:
[...]

I especially like what he says of the underlying wistfulness of life--the transcience of even a happy moment, because of life moving ever forward--I thought, how rare for a director to touch down on such a subject that is rarely spoken of.

There is no accounting for taste.
The magic of this film worked for me and for thousands of others.
But it doesn't work for everyone.

If the magic doesn't work for you that's fine.
A prior review here used considerable intellect and very good critical faculties to justify a response that is emotional and taste related.
It doesn't come close to capturing the beauty of the film.

What Anderson does miraculously is distance you with satire and artifice at the same time he draws you in emotionally with a look at good people struggling with complex feelings.
Good fairy tales do the same.
The imagery, use of music, cinematography, and script are all creative and for me were magical.

Look at Anthony Lane's review in The New Yorker. Lane is one of our better reviewers and has the expertise to look at this film far more perceptively than I can or the prior reviewer can.
You may still not like the film.

Moonrise Kingdom is a film about two 12-year old autistic kids who run away from home (and a scout camp) in order to discover their sexuality. I didn't like the film. Several scenes could be seen as normalization of paedophilia. I was glad I wasn't the only one who made the connection, since everyone was so positively smitten by this production. A similar film could easily have been done without the sexual subtexts, the weirdly effeminate male characters, the suspicious-looking narrator If Hollywood wanted to raise consciousness about autism, this probably wasn't the best way to do it!

When young Sam and Suzy (Jared Gilman and Kara Hayward) run away from an adult world that has disappointed them to build their own life together, representatives from that world (Bill Murray, Bruce Willis, Frances McDormand, and Edward Norton) attempt to track them down in the face of an approaching hurricane.

This is only the second Wes Anderson film I have seen, after Fantastic Mr. Fox, and it largely continues the whimsical, otherworldly tone of that film.  What worked so well in an animated feature could become cloying and precious in live action, but Anderson avoids this pitfall by encouraging deadpan performances from his cast that help to establish a tired, resigned melancholy as the foundation for his fable about adolescence.  The kids have been let down and think they can do it better.  The adults seem to know that they have failed their kids, but they love them and are not eager for them to rush into a premature  maturity that is bound to disappoint them as well.  The approaching hurricane that provides a ticking clock for the action serves as a potent metaphor for adolescence.  It meanders a bit but has a lot of charm and many pleasant surprises.

Moonrise Kingdom is a wonderful movie that even a bitter cynic like myself finds it impossible not to love. It's so charming, smart and funny that it's hard to imagine anyone being immune to this film's charm. It's a delightful coming of age story set in the 1960s, full of unique characters and beautiful visuals. Typical of a Wes Anderson movie, the soundtrack is brilliant. Unlike some of Anderson's more esoteric work, Moonrise Kingdom is very accessible and, along with The Grand Budapest Hotel one of his very best films. This is a film that you will want to return to again and again.

Artistically, Moonrise Kingdom is a delightfully nostalgic, creative masterpiece imbued with palpable yearnings of a simpler time and place. The interior shots evoke memories of elementary school dioramas and dollhouse miniatures. The characters are not as fully developed as they could be, and there seems to be an emphasis placed on style over substance compared to some of Andersons other films. This small criticism aside, Anderson's incredibly inventive costumes, sets, and color palette magically transport the viewer into an alternate universe that is both familiar and dreamlike. The film has underlying pathos and wistfulness, especially in the scenes between Sam and Suzy  as played by newcomers Jared Gilman and Kara Hayward. Anderson is a master at capturing the melancholy that accompanies the realization that time passes inevitably  he reminds us that it is impossible to turn back the clock, no matter how hard we try.

This is an absolutely wonderful movie. My brother showed it to me, and Wes Anderson in general, and I'm so glad he did. This quirky flick just gets better every time I watch it, which has been about once a year, when I find out one of my friends hasn't seen it yet. It's magic leaves my happy every single time I watch it, and I don't think that will every go away.

I also love Wes' directorial style as well. His distinctly quirky "Rule of Third's" cinematography is immediately recognizable, and always serves to further his purpose of delivering a fantastically unique, engaging, and charming story.

The acting is superb, and even the young kids did a great job. This is actually very important, as two of the young kids are the main characters, and get a large amount of screen time. It's funny to see Bruce Willis in a very submissive role, contrary to his usual macho persona. He pulls it off surprisingly well though, and delivers a surprisingly good and well fit performance. Edward Norton and Bill Murray did fantastic, as usual, and succeeded in adding to the movie's atmosphere.

So yes, I would definitely recommend this movie, especially if you're a fan of any of Wes Anderson's other films. Awesome acting, directing, cinematography, and music really make this movie the whole package.

I grew up in the era this film represents, and I have to say, Wes Anderson captures the spirit and ambience of the times better than most of my own memories.  I've long sentimentalized the popular culture I remember.......sleeping bags lined with flannel prints of the north woods, Indian motifs, plaids, New England scenery and everything scouting.  This film romantically stylizes these elements, infusing all with a golden light of nostalgia.  The story draws from the innocence and rebelliousness of childhood fantasies of running away and living off the land, with ideal casting that includes a quirky pair of young romantic leads and endearingly fallible adults.  Add the most fantastic soundtrack since, well, ever.....and like me, you may want to own both the DVD and the soundtrack.  I hope you are enchanted by this charming, idiosyncratic film as much as I am!

I don't think this is a movie for children, or even for families. People seem to be thrown off by the main characters and think it is a kids' movie, but it isn't. It is PG-13, not PG or G. It is for an adult or late teen audience, and I think even the latter might not "get it."  The cast is great, and Willis' performance is especially touching. I always thought he was great when he takes it down a notch and actually acts (see "Unbreakable" or "Sixth Sense" or even Moonlighting"!).  I responded to someone else's review in what I hope was a respectful manner - I think Anderson's films are an acquired taste and you either like them or you don't. Neither should be faulted - it is just a personal choice. LOL....  Loved Royal Tennenbaums and Grand Budapest Hotel too - but you miss out when you watch them on a small screen.

Based on the high number of 5 star ratings and the fact that it was purported to be a good romance and comedy film (essentially suggesting that it was good for families), I took a chance. I had no problems with the comedy aspects of this movie. The humor was subtle, much like many British comedies, but I like that kind of off-beat humor. My biggest problem with the film was that it centered around an adolescent love affair between two 12 year olds, each of whom had problems with their parental relationships. They run away and decide flee to the wilderness where they could live out their lives together. While there is no nudity in this film, there are a few scenes where the sexual discussions and physical contact are inappropriate, especially for 12 year olds. Later in the movie, after they are located and brought back to the scout camp where the boy had escaped, one of the scout leaders agrees to marry them (kind of) and help them escape again. I was really turned off by the basic concept of the movie and by the portrayal that this kind of young love should be both accepted and encouraged.

For example, Bruce Willis in a non action role.  Bill Murray is perfect for the genre if it could be called a genre.  (The Wes Anderson Genre?).  There is a quirky narrator who we see (vs voiceover) and who even gets into the action.  Tilda Swinton plays "Social Services", a single character embodiment of bureaucratese.  It is a comedy told as a touching coming of age story. There are no hero's or villians just endearing human foibles.

In 2012 there were two films that absolutely charmed the socks off me. One was Beasts of the Southern Wild; the other was Moonrise Kingdom. Now normally, I'm not a big Wes Anderson fan. The only other Anderson film that I thought worth having in my library is Fantastic Mr. Fox. Even the recent Grand Budapest Hotel--for all its spectacular design and artistry--just didn't get to me. But Moonrise Kingdom is such a terrific time trip back to 1965--every detail perfect, in its depiction of a summer holiday island. Moreover, its whimsical and ravishing depiction of very young love--and the huge risks one takes for it--is spot on. The romance of Sam and Suzy is a wonderful portrait of the first clumsy, dazzling infatuation with the opposite sex. Their escape to live in the woods together is classic. And Anderson's cast? To die for! Murray, McDormand, Swinton, Norton, Willis, Keitel, Schwartzman, Balaban, et al. If you love romantic comedy, as I do, you have to have Moonrise Kingdom. One technical caveat, though. I bought the Blu Ray from Amazon UK, which presumably is the same as the US version. Most of the transfer is visually mediocre--not Blu Ray-sharp quality, but ordinary DVD visual quality. My advice, save money and get the DVD instead. P.S. There's apparently a Criterion version available which, I would hope, will have better image quality. It will certain cost a lot more.

I'm glad Wes Anderson makes movies, I just don't know what he makes them for. This is not film noir. Yes, there's a story -- good guys and bad guys even, the bad guys being the oldest -- but does anyone really take it seriously? And that's the problem w his films. Two hours (or 90 minutes) of froth. I admire most Anderson films, I've never gotten lost in any of them, save The Royal Tenenbaums, his masterwork, for my money. And this is a very sweet story, I do get the sense that Sam and Suzy care for each other, belong together. But.... but...

Certainly worth watching, though not the best example of one of my film-watching rules of thumb: the better the performances by your least-favorite actors -- Edward Norton, Bruce Willis -- the better the film.

For me, the color and texture of this Wes Anderson film stands above all his others. Only GBH comes close to tying.

Anderson creates a world of misfits, awkward, but charming. Everyone is seeking an escape: via romamce, imagination, summer camp programs, costumes, thoughts of self pity, disowning, death and of course literally (escaping on the island).

Everyone is different and yet everyone is the same (hiding in their futile efforts to escape the banality of their chosen, regular lives). Only the two kids, outcasts who embrace their otherness,  rise above, discovering in reality what others can only imagine.

Their actions are the catalyst for everyone else on the island to finally own their own lives as well, achieving something far greater than all the hiding and pretending every could.

And the music is phenomenal.

I have very conflicting emotions about the films of Wes Anderson. On the pro side he has a visual eye for composition that seems antithetical to the nauseating hand held camera style and the films a beautiful to look at His choices of accompanying music is superb and draws from an ecclectic selection, especially The Darjeeling Limited which was the CD that occupied my portable CD player (this being before I had an Ipod) for an entire week after purchase. But on the negative side his films are hollow on the inside and his characters are oftentimes too quirky for their own good where it actually strains their likability as well their credibiliy even within context of the film. When I watch the Wizard of Oz I have no problem with Dorothy's trip to Oz or any of the inhabitants because it creates its own cinematic gravity but Wes Anderson makes his characters so stiffly mannered at times that they come of a life size dolls reciting recorded dialogue. In all his films (that I've at least) I felt no great interest or sympathy for any of his characters because there is never any real need to. I used to look forward to a new Wes Anderson film but lately (especially after The Hotel Budapest) not so much. As to Moonrise Kingdom I can only say that I liked the kids and their own adventure (despite a couple moments of sexuality that seemed creepy and out of place) but the rest of the cast were the standard assortment of Anderson oddities. Bill Murray sleepwalks through his few scenes. Edward Norton is annoying. Tilda Swinton is....well, Tilda Swinton and not much of a character. Bruce Willis was a bit more grounded in reality and was the best adult character on the film. There is a silly moment toward the end involving Willis and the two children and how this is resolved seems to be a big FU to the audience as they seemed to have painted themselves into corner they didn't have the imagination to get out of with any degree of plausibility. If Buster Keaton were given a similar scene he would have figured out a brilliant way to end it without just cutting away from it. I did not wholly dislike the film but it was very disappointing and is another example why Wes Anderson films are getting more and more superficial and frivilous as the years go on. He needs to find a good book to adapt (and I don't mean another Roald Dahl book) to apply his superior visual sense to. There is no shame in not producing one's own material.....Kubrick made a career out of adapting books---only his first two films were of his creation and he pretty much dismissed them as amateurish exercises. Herein lays the rub with Wes Anderson who should be making great films instead of wasting time and money on these cinematic bon bons.

This film is a brilliant tribute to the devotion possible in young/first love.  It happens in a surreal world where the young lovers, though far from typical children, are the least eccentric occupants.  They are clearly out of step with their peers, but not with each other.  The ensemble cast is great and often cast against the grain - A quirky group of  often brooding people living in a picturesque, if foreboding, place.  The story takes place in the 60s, seemingly before the sexual revolution, and its sexual tension is innocent and child-like as appropriate to the time.  It was the first film for Jared Gilman and Kara Hayward and they play characters their own ages (both were born in late 1998).  They are portrayed as the children they are, but wise and serious beyond their years.  Try not to read plot synopses before watching the film.  It is much better to experience it as it moves along and the ending is charming.

The two pre teen peformers do a terrific job of portraying the awkwardness, yet profound feelings of two youngsters finding each other and themselves in a youngsters' world in which they do not seem to fit. Bruce Willis plays a substantially different role than I was used to seeing him in. Ed Norton plays a nerdish scout master, who ends up doing the "right thing". The rest of the supporting cast is great as well. They just seem to be having a lot of fun. This is a movie where the kids act more like adults and vice versa.

Here's another story from Wes Anderson about people who are very smart.  The interesting thing about smart people is that they are so stupid about some things even though they are smart about the things they know about.  This can be particularly poignant during the transition out of childhood, and was even more so back in the 1960s, when this story takes place, when the struggle to piece together sensible information about romance and sexuality took place without the internet or much cooperation at all from the adult world.

Yet even within the storm of misinformation, certain truths come shining through, so clear that a kid can invest major emotion and will into a relationship that befuddles and enrages adult observers.

Thus the world of Moonrise Kingdom.  There are structural limitations on the lives of the leading players, two adolescents who find a common spark, but along with the ambition of their connection comes the clear intuition or realization that these limitations are phony, or unfulfillable, or for some reason just do not and cannot apply to their own lives.

I have a great sympathy for the bizarre, romantic, inescapably intellectual search for meaning which this story follows.  I also love the setting, the surrounding characters, place, and time, and the chain of events which get us from point A to point Z.  This is almost too kooky to be fiction.

Wes Anderson,is a director that has an untouched pristine vision,fully-story-boarded,in primary colours. He imagines closed worlds or communities,backed up by costumes and music,the characters are an extension of the clothes and manufactured sets. Does he repeat himself?Does he exclude reality?Is he trying to contrast amateur worlds with professional worlds,adults and adolescents,the messy grown-ups and the single-minded kids?Is first love like a state of Eden,with the island inlet where the children escape to to fully experience that love,no longer existent? Do the adults see this intensity beyond their control so threatening? Common to all his films isa cast of well known actors(Willis,Norton,Murray,McDormand,Keitel,Swinton) who are asked to play painted figurines in the background of this clockwork universe.

Andersons composer of choice is Benjamin Britten,his Noyes Fludde and The Young Persons Guide to the Orchestra. Britten wrote very well for children,providing the sound-world of the movie. Noyes Fludde suggests the world of amateurdramatics, that conjures up the spirit of this movie. Of course Hank Williams has been thrown in to echo to Captain Sharps(Willis) doleful presence. The two children are running away from worlds of emotional absence and trauma. Suzys(Kara Hayward) parents (Mc Dormand and Murray) alert the local sheriff Captain Sharp(with whom Mrs Bishop/McDormand is having an affair).Sam(Jared Gilman) has disappeared from a Scout camp, with his map-reading and bush-keeping skills to look after his beloved, Suzy,who brings along her binoculars,battery-operated record-player andfluorescent adventure books. They elude parents,police, social services and fellow Scouts,are caught and escape again against a backdrop of raging storms and parental discord. There is no development of character,there is only surface depth,deadpan emotions.

I liked the film,it was funny,clever,beautifully constructed,artfully composed,full of great pop music of the 60s,the two children were brilliant,full of choreographed zany energy and spontaneity,and there was enough insertion of accidental happenstance to upset the predetermined elements in Andersons head with tremendous luck.

Wes Anderson's unique style is not for everyone, but personally I enjoy his movies. This movie is set in a sterilized view of 1965 on an island somewhere in the northeastern United States. Wes uses bright and colorful sets with intense, flamboyant characters yet deadpan humor similar to what he used in "The Royal Tenenbaums" and "The Grand Budapest Hotel" and in some ways "The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou" but this movie has more "laugh out loud" scenes.

The plot is moderately complicated containing many situations and problems being dealt with by characters other than the two twelve-year-olds who ran away and things are further complicated by a major hurricane hitting the area.

There were a couple of plot points which I predicted before they materialized, but that did not take away from my enjoyment of the movie. I was disappointed with one scene between Bruce Willis and Tilda Swinton. When Captain Sharp (Willis) and Social Services (Swinton) face-off against each other I was reminded of a scenes from Walt Disney's "The Last Electric Knight" where detective Jake Rizo (Gil Gerard) faced-off against the supervisor from Social Services. Unfortunately in a comparison between the two Wes Anderson fell short of Walt Disney in fulfilling the potential for this scene. However, if you have not seen "The Last Electric Knight" I doubt you will feel let down by Wes Anderson's scene.

While on the subject of Bruce Willis, while all of the characters are unique Wes Anderson characters, I especially liked Bruce Willis as Captain Sharp. While the character still has Bruce Willis' unique subtlety, Captain Sharp was at the same time a unique Wes Anderson character. Bruce Willis' subtlety in his portrayal of characters and Wes Anderson's character's subtlety are a perfect match.

In summary, the way you felt about "The Royal Tenenbaums" and "The Grand Budapest Hotel" is probably how you will feel about "Moonrise Kingdom". Personally I loved them all.
Wonderful; a real journey to a bygone age of innocent American childhood.  Wes Anderson has the ability to create places you want to return to, even if you've never been there.

My wife and I really enjoyed this fun, intelligent film from Wes Anderson about young love and coming of age in a 1960s-era sleepaway camp. Set against the backdrop of an impending hurricane (you find this out in the first couple of minutes, so I'm not giving anything away), the tension slowly but constantly builds, compounded by other story elements that thicken the plot. The dialog is witty, if not a bit dry, particularly for the two main protagonists, but that's the film-maker's style; think Rushmore, or The Royal Tenenbaums. You either like it or you don't. I do. There's also a wonderful synchronicity between Anderson's unfolding story and Benjamin Britten's "Noye's Fludde," both musically and thematically.

Disclaimer: I'm a huge Wes Anderson fan. That said, I enjoyed this movie immensely. It's a charming, quirky story about young people who don't fit in, just trying to find some kind of belonging. Like most other Wes Anderson faire, it's also a joy to behold. The cinematography is austere, the color palettes are vivid and powerfully presented, clearly chosen to convey specific emotions in any given scene. If you're a fan of Wes Anderson, you really owe it to yourself to see this movie. If you've never seen a Wes Anderson film but you're sick of the typical hollywood bluster, in this man's films you'll find a delightfully quirky, yet humanistically grounded way of storytelling that you might just fall in love with.

Even though it sometimes does, nothing has to blow-up, and the chase can be a slow one. Young love can capture your imagination just as well as the sex that leaves nothing to the imagination can capture ticket sales. In fact, each lovely scene, and quick witted line is more appreciated for the lack of that other garbage, making this a far better film.
What makes this "far better" than most? Charm, sweetness, understated treatment by outstanding actors that do not steal the heart away from the characters they lovingly portray, and, of course, writing. This was all orchestrated as the appreciation of orchestra for the young explains throughout, by Wes Anderson: one piece, one section, one breath, and stroke at a time, put together, just so.
Sweetest love story in zany 60s scouting and camping drag.

I wouldn't call this a great movie, but I don't feel I wasted an hour and a half of my life. I admit, I feel it's a very cerebral childhood love story being told here, and while the script tries to make it seem like more than it is, it's just two kids who are both unhappy with their lives living in a romantic fantasy world. I just feel that, when the story is boiled down, you have an orphan with social issues and a wealthy girl with homicidal issues and no one willing to take actual steps to helping them.

If you've never seen a Wes Anderson film, this is a great place to start.

Moonrise Kingdom is a sad, sweet love story about two misfit, outcast pre-teens who plot to run away together in 1965. The touching script alone, filled with precocious children and sad adults, is worth the price of admission.

But of course, what you get with a Wes Anderson film is so much more. Striking colors. Exaggerated dolly shots. Sweeping camera pans. Sharp cuts and zooms. And of course, very quirky characters. Elements of magical realism (like an impossibly high tree house, a character struck by lightning, or the strangely elaborate infrastructure of the fictional Khaki Scouts) help you suspend your sense of place and realize that you're in a fairy tale.

And the soundtrack is inspired! the music switches back and forth between Benjamin Britten and Hank Williams, and it just works, propelling the story forward in a way that you just don't want it to stop.

I dare you not to fall in love with this film. I think I'll go watch it again.

I think Wes Anderson's biggest fans are the folks who grew up losing themselves and having their imaginations blossom reading the very same type of books his young leading lady reads in this film.  I find all of his movies are a tribute to those many 20th century books written for the eight to twelve year old target market. Upon writing this, I realize the some what deadpan line delivery that has become a distinct aspect of his style, resembles that of a child reading just such a book and is probably intentional.  His films tend to always hit me with an unexpected, and usually unexplainable wave of emotion at the end, which always brings about reflection days after, and not just on the movie, but my own life. "Moonrise Kingdom" is no exception. He is an acquired taste that not everyone gets, which is also part of his appeal.  Upon looking back at his filmography I have a hard time putting any of his movies in front of another.  If I were to ever rank his movies in a list I know "Moonrise Kingdom" would be far from the bottom.

I would recommend you watch it to make sure that
It was quirky, funny and odd but I liked it. Bruce Willis & Bill Murray did a pretty good job of playing the part of weirdo's.

This film harkens to a day when things were simpler and you didn't need lots of special effects, sex, or explosions to make a movie successful. An incredibly fun story of young love and adventure that is brought to life with fantastic acting and the style that is unmistakably Wes Anderson.

Being a huge fan of Wes Anderson movies, this does not disappoint.  It brings back memories
of growing up in a nostalgic time and first love.  A true delight to watch.
Great casting, directing, soundtrack and story! A funny tale of two displaced children from dysfunctional circumstances that appear to be old souls finding their way to one another.
Not bad, but not great either. My 13 and 15 year old kids didn't get it and were bored and lost interest.

One of Wes Anderson's best works in my opinion. As someone who only recently discovered the talented director, I was more than pleasantly surprised at the emotion of the film. Now used to Anderson's cinematography and style of dialogue, along with the coolest cast of actors that continually pop up in Anderson films, it's easy to get hooked on this film. It's witty, funny and endearing. The love story, the family dynamics and the natural disaster all roll together to make something that will leave you feeling good at the end of the movie.

A delightful movie with quirky off beat characters and a wonderful cast.
Anderson is different, no doubt about it, but different in a wonderful way.
If you are one of those who gave this one or two stars, well in a way I feel sorry for you.
Unclench your keister and enjoy this delightful film.

This is not standard fare American movie making.  As my wife said, "Quirky."

I would give it 5 stars, but I want to reserve 5 for the greatest movies of all time.  Moonrise Kingdom was incredibly good, but not the one of the greatest movies of all time (like Rushmore or Life Aquatic).  This movie was so much fun to watch.  The acting was fantastic.  The cinematography was perfect.  I highly recommend it.

The hyper-stylized world of Anderson takes you on a journey well beyond your couch. The writing perfectly captures the bitter sweetness of childhood-delving into darker aspects of growing up. The characters are complex; the performances of Kara Hayward and Jared Gilman are especially strong. This surface love story undergoes a metamorphosis into the poignant tale of two outcasts finding a place within each other.

Wes Anderson does it again. This one is good for families, whereas other Wes Anderson films have dark moments that get violent or bloody. This doesn't have that. Its themes are travel and childhood and it is really really funny.

I loved the movie, but it's not a typical Bruce Willis movie.  If you want his usual action packed, speed 'em up, shoot 'em all, save the day type movie, then this is not for you.  It's just a simple movie about growing up. Yes, I would recommend this movie.

Like any Wes Anderson movie, "Moonrise Kingdom" is literally a journey into a place that, 'if it isn't real, it should be,' to paraphrase Winston. It has that amazing earnestness that children are capable of bringing to the silliest things, taken to absurdly mature extremes: running off to live with your lover; chasing down anybody who breaks your club's rules, armed with improvised maces with nails sticking out of them  this is Wes Anderson's Vietnam movie. It's the 60's generation, as twelve year olds. The ones who follow the rules, the counter-culture kids who break them, the clueless parents, and a storm coming to destroy them.
  You can see seeds that will grow into the dark themes of Anderson's "Grand Budapest Hotel" in this stuff, but it still has the weightlessness (in a great way) of a child's game, by and large. Anderson has always been exquisitely precise in his ability to depict death: Max sitting at his Mother's grave in "Rushmore," Richie's suicide attempt in "Tenenbaums," Sam the orphan here. The resonance of loss, the yearning for love  the perfect safety of an Arcadian realm, carved out of and separate from the world. It's the goal of so many of his best characters (almost all of them, really), and an act of will they share with their creator.
  If you've enjoyed any of Wes Anderson's movies, I think you'll love this one. If you've never seen one, this would be a great gateway drug. If you've seen them all... maybe you'll share my secret belief that Sam could grow up to be Bert Fischer. I don't know why that made me so happy, walking out of the theatre, but it really did.

Wes Anderson is to film what primitive painters are to art. They communicate the way they see truth in a highly stylized way. Moonrise Kingdom is a film you must watch on Wes Anderson's terms, or you won't enjoy it. The cast  has first rate character actors like Harvey Keitel, Bob Balaban and Tilda Swinton. Bruce Willis plays a lonely police chief who runs a one-man police department. Bill Murray and Frances McDormand are lawyers locked in an unhappy marriage. But the stars of this film are the two young actors who play the star-crossed lovers: Jared Gilman as Sam and Kara Hayward as Suzy. These two are drawn together because they are kindred spirits and feel unloved and rejected by their peers and families. Sam actually is a foster child. I won't provide spoilers, but it's fair to say they have a series of adventures and mis-adventures which will both amuse and touch you. The film has a dramatic theme, but Anderson maintains an undercurrent of humor throughout. This is the kind of film you will want to see more than once. It not only has a coherent plot, but also has a happy ending. If you happen to have seen Wes Anderson's latest film, the Grand Budapest Hotlel and enjoyed it, you will definitely enjoy Moonrise Kingdom.

Great movie, good fun, and this version came with Blu-Ray/DVD and digital copy *and* a VUDU/Ultraviolet copy AND a free rental through Amazon as a bonus, even though why I would rent a movie I'd just purchased in four different formats I am unsure of, but still, it was a pleasant surprise with my confirmation email.

A++ would not buy again, BECAUSE I ALREADY HAVE SO MANY VERSIONS OF IT!

Although enjoyable overall, I did not find this to be Wes Anderson's strongest work. The characters were not as developed as they are in his other films and I found the film was lacking in attachments to the characters on an emotional level.

Still, there were plenty of good moments to entertain none the less, so I did not feel my time was wasted.
This original, imaginative film is a delight from start to finish. I'm surprised it hasn't been seen by more people.
Brilliant, humorous and thought provoking. This and the Grand Budapest Hotel exude pure genius in writing, production, cinema photography and casting.
Great fun to watch.  Performances were terrific.  A wonderful film for all Wes Anderson fans.  For viewers who are not yet Wes Anderson fans this movie will make them one.

Cant beat this one.  Best in a while of young romance gone awry on a tiny island with boy scouts and a single island policeman attempting to locate the fallen in love runaways.  From start to finish, this one is enjoyable!
loved the quirky characters, the time period, super acting. A refreshing movie to see more than once. Also beautiful scenery.

Worse movie I ever saw.

The kids! Great performances! Great writing! Great little movie!
Great flick when you don't know what to watch. Great cinematography , excellent cast, wild plot  and characters . Totally enjoyed this movie .

Sublime, perfectly paced, sweet, and oddly hilarious.
Watch all of Wes Anderson's movies and develop a new appreciation for film life.
How could a movie with so many stars stink so badly?  I wish I could remove it from my memory.

What a great film.  Wes Anderson, once again creates a beautiful stylized work.  His writing and direction of two young child actors is nothing short of remarkable.  Oh, and its sweet, funny and very fun to watch.

Moonrise Kingdom will take you back to your childhood, your first camping trip, your first fish caught, your first kiss. It captures (what I imagine) 1965 was like in a unique way. Too humorous to be taken seriously, it has enough emotional moments to be memorable. It is loaded with excellent camera angles and has a unique form of narration. Perhaps most importantly, it is a movie about freedom, independence, and true love. It throws in some useful survival tips and also shows how great the Boy Scouts are. The two newcomers (Jared Gilman and Kara Hayward) play the 12 year olds and they are both so precious they steal the show hands-down from a star-studded cast. A slightly risqu (given her age and beauty) version of Dorothy from the Wizard of Oz, Suzy in "knee socks and Sunday School shoes" has a wardrobe that is classic.

This surreally-gorgeous coming-of-age film offers a panoramic array of moviegoing riches: beauty;  humor;  love, honor and loyalty; suspense;  adventure;  a unique and perfect soundtrack: you won't be disappointed!

Sam was great, the girl's name I forget, but she was spooky, but great also.  Fun story,
fun presentation. A theme that is plausible, first love can last forever.

This is as original, quirky and endearing as a movie can get - I love it, and have added it to my permanent collection to watch whenever and wherever.  Chock full of eccentric characters, each actor and actress, plunging headlong into their respective roles with vigor and enthusiasm - no typecasting here!  As to the plot, well it's a contemporary take on Romeo and Juliet, with the astonishingly young hero and heroine, overcoming every challenge and villain in the way of love that transcends adolescence, set  in a sort of scout-style island summer camp with a vague Lord of the Flies undercurrent, and many adult malcontents adding amusing complexity to the story line.  These adults don't seem to have a clue what's going on right beneath their noses, being as self-absorbed as they are, with their own silliness.  I'd call it delightful adult entertainment that will also appeal to youngsters and the young-at heart of any age, eight to eighty.

I used to think that Royal Tannenbaums was my favorite Wes Anderson movie. I was wrong. It is this one. I love this movie so much.

This magical journey back to the early teen years evokes the emotions of the teen years: euphoric or deeply depressed, there are no in betweens. The story of young almost love (love without knowing it is love) is warm and reminiscent of a Norman Rockwell painting. Innocence and love coexist; the entire cast is heartwarming.
Different and amazing awesomeness, don't miss out on this great movie that will melt your heart and brain to a wonderful goo!

Thanks to two appealing juvenile leads, Wes Anderson's "Moonrise Kingdom" succeeds in engaging and sometimes moving us.  Set in coastal New England in 1965, it is about two misfit thirteen-year-olds who fall in love (each, it seems, intuiting the other's "misfittedness") and decide to run away together and set up a home/camp where they can live isolated from the world of their parents and other adult authorities.  Since the boy, Sam, has survival skills (he runs away from a scout camp) and the girl, Suzy, is as resourceful in her way (she brings the scissors and other things), they do pretty well.  Suzy's parents are two lawyers (Bill Murray and Frances McDormand) who seem as indifferent to each other as they are to their children, and their marital conversation is mainly about the cases they're working on.  The fact that the mother communicates with her children via bullhorn is obviously both funny and pointed.  Sam is an orphan in foster care, and Edward Norton is the well-meaning scoutmaster of Sam's troop.  These three adults and the local sheriff (Bruce Willis) are the ones who have to deal with the fact that the young people have run off.

All of that seems ordinary enough, but Anderson frames the story in interesting ways, both visually and dramaturgically.  The adult world of the scout camp and Suzy's home is presented in terms of a high degree of linear organization: rooms are boxy and behaviour is regimented to a cartoonish extent, and the regimentation of the scout troop is very clear, and the impression that the viewer gets is of two young people trying to get away from life in a cartoon and escape into something more authentic.  The parents and scoutmaster are emotionally incompetent to a comic degree, and the only adult who seems to have an inkling of the kind of freer life the young people want is the sheriff, who in a climactic scene faces down Social Services.  Tilda Swindon literally calls herself "Social Services" and that tells us all we need to know about the "flattening" of most of the adult figures in the movie.  Swindon is marvelous in the role, and Bruce Willis as her antagonist gives a performance of great charm.  Bill Murray here has a role that fits well with his usual deadpan affectless schtick, but he remains, for me at least, a very limited actor.  In the course of the movie most of the adults unfreeze to some extent.  McDormand, who is presented as being drawn to the sheriff, has a touching scene with her daughter at the end.

Jared Gilman and Kara Hayward are Sam and Suzy.  Neither actually says "There must be more to life than this" as they view the adult world, but the seriousness with which they take both their escape (very carefully planned) and their affection is both funny and endearing.  They are trying to act as the kind of adults that they want to be -- not the kinds of adults who have shaped their lives thus far. The deadpan seriousness with which they take all this is funny -- they even go through a form of marriage and unembarassedly acknowledge their sexual feelings, which seem to them to have nothing to do with their love, which has more to do with their mutual recognition as misfits.  The young actors pull off Anderson's conceptions of their characters just about perfectly.  One way of understanding them, I think, is to say that they want a narrative, and it's no accident that Suzy takes half-a-dozen storybooks along on the escape, and we see her read aloud from them on several occasions.  This perhaps clues us to the idea that adult life in the movie has stopped -- it has no ongoing story, at least as far as the young people can perceive, and no story means no future, so they decide to create their own.  Maybe with the onset of adolescence we all do this -- adolescent "rebellion" is a bit of a cliche, but here Anderson manages to find a fresh way of representing it.  Maybe too the allusions to Britten's children's opera "Noyes Flood" (based on a medieval drama about Noah) are deployed to suggest this: the flood (looked at it one way) is a chance for a new start, and it is seeing Suzy dressed for the part of a raven in a local performance of the opera that wins Sam's heart, so to speak.  The movie ends after its own flood (a hurricane), and if Bob Balaban, the narrator who frames the whole story, is to be believed, it ushers in a sense of renewal that extends even to the crops in subsequent years.  With that suggestion, Anderson reminds us of the apparent natural magic of renewal, not only in the natural cycle but in the revelations that can follow crises in narratives.  (To put it like that sounds heavy-handed, but the movie itself avoids the portentousness that thematic analysis is prone to fall into!)

I'll avoid spoilers, and say nothing about the fact that there are really two escapes, the details of the storm, the scout troop's pursuit of the runaways, or the sheriff's defense of Sam.  It's a comic movie, finally, and it clocks in at just about 90 minutes, so it doesn't drag.  The degree of stylization with which the adult world is presented keeps us at the distance required to appreciate both the pains of growing up, the dangers of having grown up, and the need to keep open the possibility of change and (if we're lucky) growth.

while the basic story was "all right", the production failed miserably in many ways. Wes Anderson creates a story about his vision of the world.  From Bottle Rocket to Moonrise Kingdom he has strived to bring his artistic vision to us the viewer.  Moonrise Kingdom tells a story of first love the way it should be.  A love that is borderline innocent and true at the same time.  What makes this movie five stars for me is the excellent cast as well as the sets.  Take the time and watch this movie, you will be able to see the world a little clearer.

I love to see actors step out of the usual roles they are offered. Wes Anderson never fails to give us an odd  presentation of a place and condition we would never consider. I can't wait to show this to my grown children.

I know this guy is the critics' favorite and has a dedicated groupie following; but I just don't get it.  The few I've watched, or tried to watch, were bland and droll.  Seems to be his syle. What really amazes me is his ability to get so many big name actors to appear in these financial bombs.  I would think they wouldn't want one of his box office disasters on their resume.

This one made less than $46,000,000 worldwide according to MOJO.  None of his movies have actually made much more than that, and some a lot less.  Why?  Because no one likes what he is putting out.  It's remarkable that he can keep getting financing for these bombs.  Having said all that, I at least was able to finish this  one before turning it off like I have done with some of his other films.

I rated this five stars because it is quirky, funny and very sweet.  The two main characters are very lovable, especially the boy.  Nothing horrible happens, which is quite refreshing.  Did not have to close my eyes once.
captures the spirit of being a kid and true love. hilariously quirky, visually gripping, a true masterpiece. wes Anderson has done it again

This is my favorite Wes Anderson movie if not my favorite movie ever.. Love the dry humor and the lightness of it. So thrilled to have it on every device, as I already own the iTunes version, but it is worth having it on everything!
Just love this movie, a romeo and juliet like story with rich characters and a great story, can't go wrong with Wes Anderson.

Set in 1965, "Moonrise Kingdom" captures a summer adventure/romance between two quirky outcast 12-year olds, Sam and Suzy. Suzy is the only daughter of the odd characters played by Frances McDormand and Bill Murray, both lawyers who are certainly not vying for parent of the year award. They both seem distant and mildly depressed, and in general uninterested in their 4 children. Their home near the sea on a New England island is beautifully designed set featuring large perfectly symmetrical, brightly hued rooms. It seems like a perfect place for creative children to exercise their minds. The symmetry design is carried out throughout the film, almost to excess, but is certainly a defining feature.

Sam is a 12-year old orphan, residing in a foster home and spending the summer in Khaki Scouts camp, lead by Ed Norton. Sam and Suzy carry on a pen pal correspondence for a while, before they agree to run away together. Sam has planned a scouting expedition in great detail, and Suzy brings along her battery operated phonograph and favorite books. The relationship between these two like minded adolescents is charming and fun, though it borders on the uncomfortable when then start to explore their sexuality.

The search for the two runaways is lead by Bruce Willis, only member of the Island Police Force. The Khaki Scout troop is also pressed into service to locate their fallen comrade.

"Moonrise Kingdom" is not exactly a drama, not exactly a comedy, but is certainly interesting, quirky and whimsical. The set design and cinematography are stunning, the all-star cast play understated roles, and the whole adds up to an interesting and entertaining experience.
Perfect Gift for my Wes Anderson obsessed boyfriend! I'm not a fan of this movie but he absolutely loved it :) And it got here super fast too!
I was very pleasantly surprised by this movie.  Really loved it.  Artsy fartsy with all kinds of quirky characters.  Very good!
