OMG ~ I have seen this movie 6 times and that is not enough. Each time I see something that I had missed previously. It is soooooooo delightful. And I'm 72 yr old, just so you know.

My daughter and I love the more obscure, not so publicized movies; and this one was definitely a winner. Lots of humor as well as touching moments. You'll be surprised at all the stars in this. This is a perfect movie for young teens as well as adults.

An ececelantix movie inw every way imaginable. Story, plot.acting and story.
I have not loved any movie. this much since the life aqueix.
Great movie, especially if you have a scouting history.  Lots of funny situations, in a very nice story.  Enjoyed it.
... but the movie far exceeded my expectations.  Lovely, insightful, charming, beautifully acted film; strong performances from so many fine actors.  Worth watching again.
i liked this movie. just saw the trailer before watching another movie and it looked interesting. and it was/is la

A fairly light-hearted, affirming story about young love and doing what's right. Some unrealistic action segments add to the sense of childhood fantasy. Funny, touching, and clever. One scene of adolescent sexuality I would prefer wasn't there so I could not feel guilty watching with my kids... but maybe that's my problem! If you like Wes's other films, you'll like this one. It's a bit "sweeter" than most, but it still resonates.

I purchased this lovely little DVD for $2.00 at my local store. It was originally supposed to be rented out, but no one rented it- and the poor little thing was left in a dusty pile in a 'sale bin'. Such an undeserving place for a magnificent film. I'd read many beautiful reviews about it online and always wanted to see it- but living in rural Alaska we don't have any place to buy such a thing (and I rarely buy movies anyways). So when I came across this at such a very affordable price, I snatched it up, carefully carried it home, and watched it almost immediately.

I loved it dearly, but I know it has received some interesting view-points from its audience. The content, although childish, is quite mature. There are a few scenes many may find inappropriate. But I found them truthfully captured for what they are- an accurate portrayal of pre-adult love. They are tastefully captured, as not to exploit the children, but rather to simply show the world what they are experiencing. The awkward yet comfortable first experiences of finding 'the one' (or at least the one you think is 'the one').

The scenery is magnificent and the acting by all people involved is exquisite. I was especially blown away by the younger characters and how well each one of them shown on screen. The dialogue, although quick-witted and sarcastically-humorous was delightful in it's own unique way. This is the first film I have seen by this director, but after watching it I look forward to viewing more of his work. I absolutely loved how simply the dialogue was, yet how complex the storyline it was involved in happened to be. It was a combination of amazing script writing and well-done filmography. All of the actors and actresses played their parts just right. I really couldn't imagine anyone else being cast for each of the parts. I fell in love with each and every character (aside from, of course, the social worker- who I'm fairly sure was not meant to fall in love with).

For those who have not yet witnessed the movie and are reading reviews in hopes of an overview here is a short bit about what this movie is about: The movie takes place on a lovely little island. On the island there is a camp where boys meet and essentially become, what is similar to, boy scouts (in a more modern and less judgmental sense). One boy who attends this camp is a foster child, moved amidst many homes, and in dire need of a direction in life. On the other side of the island lives a family with two parental lawyers and four odd-in-their-own-way children. The eldest is a girl, whom I related to quite closely. A girl stuck in the position of moving forward to adulthood a bit too fast, being held back by parents who don't care as much as they should, yet too much in the wrong way. What more fitting couple than the lost foster child and the strong-willed daughter of a lawyer couple. So, alas, they run away together. And so the story begins. Young love in it's truest form, amidst not the most intelligent of decisions.

The storyline was beautifully drawn out in a way that explores adolescent love for what it is; often condemned by adults and yearned for by those young and lucky enough to find it. I know that many people seem to think otherwise, and find the storyline to be inappropriate. The film does accurately portray some of the more... adult-themed actions of young adults. Many find this distasteful. But I found it honest, and the backdrop it was told amidst was just beautiful. I'm in love, and Moonrise Kingdom is among one of my very favorite movies. I can't really compare it to anything else- it's wonderful all on its own.

This wonderful, sweet film is heartwarming and uplifting. Everyone we already know and love who star in it are absolutely amazing, and the two newcomers are extraordinary. All the kids, in fact, are great in this film. It's funny, it's sweet, it's maddening at times but always charming. Always charming. It's absolutely one of the best movies I've seen in a while. Highly recommend.
This is a fantastic movie. It is a great story and is directed beautifully. This movie turned me into a Wes Anderson fan.

I first saw this movie on TV and at first I was going to switch channels but since there was nothing else better on that night, I stuck with it thru the end. WOW!!! Never seen a movie like that before (I think). The LOCATION (been/lived in RI) was great! The story kept me glued to my TV and the two (2) kids (main characters) were great!!! So I bought it!! It's definitely worth watching!
Leroy

I'm a big fan of offbeat gems like this one, (Rushmore, etc. come to mind).  Great stars giving spot on performances with a great story line that will bring back memories of camp, scouts, first loves, etc.  Thoroughly enjoyable!

This movie is absolutely enchanting IF you want to reconnect with the child you were at age 12... the kid who believed all kinds of surreal things could happen, just because you wished them to happen.

This isn't a simple, happy story. It's complex. It has some dark aspects and implications. It ends in a way that will make you say, "Oh."

And then, if you're like me, you'll watch it again, a week later.

I bought this because a friend suggested it, to get a better understanding of stereotypes and their use in stories.  This movie IS wall-to-wall stereotypes... and they're people we've all known and loved. Or hated. Or just had to stare at because they were... well, stereotypes, and you just can't get enough of that weirdness.

This is probably a love-it-or-hate-it movie.  I loved it.  I liked it far better than Royal Tenenbaums, which had its own charm but didn't capture youthful idealism as well as this movie does.

If you like predictable movies well-grounded in reality, run in the other direction. This isn't for you.

If you like offbeat films that require suspending disbelief -- and make that effort worthwhile -- this movie is a must-see.

The acting is flawless. The artistic direction is a delight. The casting is perfect. The makeup and costuming... utterly eccentric and almost a parody of that era, but -- at the same time -- not too far from fact.

There's one somewhat intimate scene that made me uncomfortable. It's not extreme. It's not total nudity or anything. I'm sure it's consistent with the rest of the film. I'm sure 12-year-olds do that sort of thing, and I'm sure it fit the writer's creative vision. It just bothered me, because the actors really _were_ 12-years-old. (I checked.)

But, except for that, I was absolutely enchanted by this film, and recommend it for fans of Wes Anderson's work.

Enjoyable family movie.  Our thirteen year old son enjoyed the movie with us. Friends that come into our lives have been
great benefactors.
Love this off beat love story. It is a must for any Wes Anderson fan. The cast is great and the filmography is beautiful!
For me, this was one of the best movies that I have seen in a while. A warm, sweet story of adolescent love. The young actors are just too swell and the adult cast is perfect.

I do not like Bruce Willis but I have to keep reminding myself of this after Red and Moonrise Kingdom.  This is a great movie and has all the things you need to write about in Screen Plays 101, a symbolic deflowering, a vision quest, oppression by the overlords (parents) and enough stuff to get an A+ if you play it right and all done by a couple of subteens that just want to run away.

This was the best quirky film and great cast of characters I've seen since Beetlejuice...Hand down.  Enjoy the film and tell me if I was right.  Go back and watch Beetlejuice, they have the same feel.  I love the director, Wes Anderson.  I hope he will direct my trilogy if I ever get it completed. Shhh.
Not joking.  I truly loved this from the first frame.  It is a Wes Anderson tour de force and something to be enjoyed again and again.

I see more subtle and clever aspect of this movie the second time I watched it. I am glad to own it, as I think there is a lot of richness I will continue to discover, each additional time I enjoy it.

Love this cute little movie and the soundtrack music. The retro tone and lighthearted aura mixed with the fabulous acting by the great actors is Moonrise kingdom. One of the best movie from Wes Anderson. Thumbs up!
Enjoyed it so much.  Great Story, great acting, Amazing direction, I completely recommend it....Very funny.  It lifted me up and carried me away through every scene!

Watched this with my family.  I expected quirky; it was a that but a little dull.  I usually enjoy quirky, but this one could have used more action and character development.  I wasn't really able to root for the lead characters until the very very end.
Absolutely loved this movie.  As a huge Wes Anderson fan, I found this one to be up there with the rest of his movies.  Cannot wait for his next one!

Wes Anderson is a genius. With that in mind, sometimes his films are a little hard to approach and adore with the reverence they deserve, but not this one. I loved every nuanced nutcase in this movie; and it says more about family values--heck, American values--than people usually calling for such things seem to ever achieve or comprehend. This film is a lovely balm when you're feeling ostracized from the human race.
One of the greater Independant films that I've seen in our time. Laugh out loud, feel good film. A must watch for the open minded cinema critic.
This is a sweet, touching, funny story that reminds us of how innocent and straightforward love can be especially for the very young.
This was not a very good movie, but then again, I had no idea what it was about when I bought it. I purchased it for my husband because he is a Bruce Willis fan.
AWFUL!!!! I just couldn't sit through this movie. Don't waste your time!!! I wish I could give a negative star!!!
A tad weirder then Wes Anderson usually goes, but still as amazing as ever. A surprisingly strong and moving love story.

We love this movie.  It is very quirky, but is filmed is such perfect balance and symmetry that you just can't take your eyes off the screen.  Loaded with stars you will want to watch it over and over again.

I don't understand why this movie has such good reviews. It's long, boring, and not funny at all. It tries to be comedic, but the gags fall flat. And what's with the artsy oddball directing? Where have we seen this before? Oh yeah, Napoleon Dynamite, a movie that actually did everything right.
This is a good movie with a star-studded cast!  I love Wes Anderson's style!  Good story and funny movie!  Wes Anderson delivers again!
I really enjoyed this movie.  I watched it several times (almost) in a row.  Very cute story, and the children are great actors!

i am a big anderson fan, but the characters really could use more fleshing out...waste of a great cast. set and costumes were great as always, but the storyline was lacking some "umph." honestly, i was kinda bored by it.
Terrific off-beat film. For fans of Wes Anderson and newbies to his oeuvre, both. Great to see with friends or family.
Capturing that awkward coming of age without pandering or giving in to the cheap joke.  The kids are smart and winning, the adults are semi-clueless.  Isn't that the way you remember it?
This film is so simple, yet complex at the same time.  I couldn't take my eyes off of the screen. Don't even get me started on the amazing music!

You just can't beat Bill Murray and Bruce Willis in this film. My wife and I laughed out loud when we had this on our weekly "Movie Night". Murray and Willis didn't carry this movie alone though. The entire cast was first rate and the storyline was fantastic. Can't say enough good things about this classic!
This movie is absolute garbage. Not worth the cellophane the DVD is wrapped in. I don't know why they bother making rubbish like this. Not even worth one star.
Great Wes Anderson film.  Who else could cast Bruce Willis in an awesome role? Cinematography is wonderful, witty and insightful.  Frances McDormand and Bill Murray are their usual best.
A truly romantic and adventurous film. My favorite of all the Wes Anderson films. The story is very sweet and as usual the art direction superb.

I adore any movie that isn't the same old tired formula of horror, CG violence, car chases and flat characters. Here is a real gem! The narrative is told like a children's book about characters all grappling with loneliness and the tone is one of innocence. Charming! And easily my favorite Wes Anderson movie.
Love this film. It's quirky, weird, funny and endearing. It took me a couple watches and I had to buy it to have it in my movie collection.

Love Wes Anderson's quirky directing.  Perfect for children's movies.  This has an all star cast but its the two unknown main characters who steal the show, who by the way are kids.  My parents found it cheesy so maybe its not for everyone but I loved this movie
Very funny movie, skillfully filmed so that every photograph looks like it came from a Norman Rockwell painting. A delightful view of young kids and how they view the world.

Love this film! Wes Anderson gets does all of the things that draw him criticism (i.e. quirky love story, bad dad, precious art direction, over head shots, check lists of items, etc.) but in this, his first period piece, it all comes together and meshes perfectly. There are some very cartoonish, out of this world moments in this movie that shouldn't make sense but do. The mail lead isn't always the most likable kid but the relationship between he and Suzy is so sweet that it can be forgiven. I also love Bruce Willis playing against type and that there is a character called Social Services.
Delightful and refreshing. A sweet "coming go age" for a boy and a girl in the '60's! Wonderful cast and lots of twists and turns! Not predictable..Enjoy
Just a great, warm movie with a great cast and good story. Wes Anderson's style may not be for everyone, but I've like almost all of his movies.

Sweet, quirky, funny and innocent love story of a capable, nerdy pre-teen and his capable though-violent-when-pressed lady love. Female character played similarly to the female character in the Royal Tennebaums, which I also liked. Very good acting. Took me a few minutes to adjust to the fake looking sets, but forgot about it once I focused on the characters.  I like this director's work, highly individualistic, and I usually find his films interesting. Rate 3 and a half stars.

This is a movie you can watch with the whole family.  It's intelligent, funny and assumes that you are too.  Great actors, smart kids (not silly or cute - but real kids) and a good script.  There's nothing not to like in this movie.
This film is Anderson's finest. Nothing surpasses it. Bellissimo. This film was simply amazing in every way possible. Hope you all enjoy.

Moonrise Kingdom tells the story of two troubled, misunderstood kids who meet and bond over their inability to fit in. Its certainly not a revolutionary plot, but this movie is anything but run-of-the-mill. Quite the opposite actually  its fantastic. Equal parts quirky, charming, witty, and genuinely funny, its a deft and completely distinctive rendition of this well-worn tale.

Therere just so many great things to say about this film. Right from the opening credits it establishes a very unique tone with the musical selection, setting, and (most notably) the camerawork. The cinematography remains consistently amazing throughout the movie, utilizing really creative, often symmetrical shot compositions and lots of side-tracking pans. The visuals play an integral role in setting the off-kilter and playful atmosphere of the film (think Fantastic Mr. Fox, Wes Andersons last film).

The cast is also excellent across the board, and whats really impressive is that the two child leads manage to steal the show from huge names like Bruce Willis, Edward Norton, Frances McDormand, and Bill Murray. And the success of the two leads isn't just due to acting ability, its also simply because the characters are really well-crafted and endearing. They both have an unabashed eccentricity and deadpan humor (think Napoleon Dynamite) that just makes them very likable and easy to root for. The deadpan humor is also a very integral part of the success of the film. Theres definitely a serious message here about never compromising who you are to fit in with crowd, but its delivered in a very light-hearted, good-humored way that never takes itself too seriously.

Overall, Moonrise Kingdom is a movie that gets nearly everything right. Its a movie during which you just cant help but smile from beginning to end and which is bursting at the seams with creativity, wit, and charm. The only real criticisms I can muster is that the middle third drags just a tad and that I wish there was a bit more resolution with Mr. and Mrs. Bishop (the parent characters of the female lead). Aside from these minor quibbles though, the movie impresses on every level and is a thoroughly entertaining and heartwarming affair.

4.5/5

This movie is simply indescribable.  It was one of the best of its year and deserved more awards than it received.  It' has an unique humor to it and in its way is quite touching.  Do yourself a favor and see this.
This movie was very overrated.  No one could stay awake throughout the movie.  I am usually a fan of the actors in the movie, but this was difficult to watch.
Wonderful entertainment.  These kids have some serious camping skills and the movie overall is great.  The love story is perfect and the young actors did a great job.

I love this movie - creative, crafty, well rendered characters and the quirkiness of youth and love without all of the sap. Intelligent when choosing the darker characteristics of the story as well as campy fun!

This is a great movie, with a great cast. The acting is so good. I'm not a person that really likes to watch movies and I would recommend this movie to anyone. I could watch this movie over and over again!

Enchanting tale of the inevitable relationship of two individuals misunderstood by their families and society.  Wonderful performances by the two child stars and the entire cast.  Stunning cinematography of a beautiful natural landscape and clever, intricate architectural set pieces.  The adult characters sympathetic to the plight of the two runaways at the center of the story (Ed Norton, Scout Master, and Bruce Willis, local cop) are particularly poignant in their connection with the boy.  Each character is treated with humor, sensitivity and love (except for the bully and the state child services rep).  As always, Wes Anderson creates a very particular world - life on an island that feels very remote and protected from the modern world.  It's a wonderful world to inhabit for 90 minutes.  And love reigns in a bold and spectacular way.
Low budget movie, simple plot, Offbeat presentation. If you like "shoot 'em, blow 'em" kind of movies, don't bother. Leaves you with food for thought. Highly recommend!
This movie is one of his best in my opinion. It's a charming love story and a New England nature lover's delight!
One of our favorite movies.  We watch it almost 3x a month!  We have even given it to family as a gift ;)

This film is rich in visual detail. You will enjoy watching it many times, and each time you will see something new, and this something new will add a new layer to the story. This also happens with the dialog, which at first listen is quite ordinary. On closer inspection, it too is full of nuance and humor. The big-name stars who appear in this film play characters who hint at their stereotypical character type but who are likeable for their quality as average folks. This is a great movie.

This film is sheer genius.  I can't think of one bad, or even mediocre, aspect of the movie.  The story is highly original, beautifully scripted, magnificently acted, brilliantly directed, and visually stunning.  If there were any award more prestigious than the Oscar, I would give it to Moonrise Kingdom in all categories.  After watching it tens of times on cable, I had to buy it so that I would always have it with me.  They just don't come any better than this.

This movie is one of the most wonderful movies I have ever seen. The actors do a great job. There is so much emotion under the surface. You have really feel the movie to see the emotions. Young love is so precious and this movie captures that first love. That first kiss, first feel. There are laugh out loud moments but there is touch story. The movie never goes off track and pulls into the station at the right time. You feel so refreshed and enjoyed the journey. The good bye is hard but you will have a satisfying feeling at the end. I feel Wes Anderson movies are made just for me. Enjoy and soak in the detail of this fantastic movie by a true master.
This was an offbeat fun kind of movie was clever, funny that had good underlying messages.  Was glad I got it.

Probably close to one of the most "unique" films I've ever seen but  that's exactly what made it so enjoyable. The first time watching I was indifferent throughout the film. I didn't exactly know what to think. But after it ended and had a chance to simmer, I was impelled to share with others and re-watch again. Definitely see this with friends or family. It only betters the experience.

Great story-line, creative film and overall a phenomenal cast. The 1960's style filming was genius and the comedy was perfect! If you haven't, be sure and add this to your Must See list.
Was a very WEIRD movie for me some scenes should not have been in movie ... I might have to watch it again to see if something was in I missed?! Certainly not what I expected  ...
Clever, beautifully directed and acted; highly stylized and nuanced.  A movie that stays with for a few days after watching.
first I enjoy Bruce Willis he was very good in this movie plus I enjoyed the movie very much I do at times think it could make more of these a good movie to see
This movie is quirky.  It has its funny moments as well as its sad.  There is a great love story. It is a must watch/buy!

This film blew my socks off! It works for me on SO many levels: a Love story, Romeo and Juliet style, part Peter Pan, the Celebration of the individual, the cold, unfeeling adults and social system, and part "Elvira Madigan", sans the Mozart. A Lovely, Inspiring film...

Child acting at its best. Many memorable scenes and lines- showing that early adolescence is crazy but truly wonderful at the same time. Back in American history when kids were expected to explore the world- with all the scariness that goes with it.

Excellent movie that you will find yourself completely immersed in. Acting is superb especially by the young leads. Fraught with humor and unexpected quirks, Moonrise Kingdom will leave you with a smile.
If you like Mr. Anderson you will want this in your collection!  It's nostalgia done oh so sweetly. It's right up there fighting to be his best.
Great movie. If you love Wes Anderson you will love this. Very cute, if you have half a brain then give it a watch.

Quirky coming of age film that is touching and heartwarming.  Loved the location...coastal New England Island.
Solid performance by Bruce Willis
never underestimate the power of lust or love, beautiful scenes, made me feel like I was there...too bad the doggy died that was the saddest part. loved the ending

If you remember anything of the 60's, you'll relate to all of this film.  The casting is superb, from the top named stars, to the unknowns.  Just a joy to watch.  The musical score is also a major part of the film and helps make it more memorable.
I enjoyed every minute of it. This movie is adorable. My daughter and I both love it - she's 20
It was a cute, goofy film.  That's all she wrote . . . I would not recommend for children 12 and under.
It was a querky but good movies. The actors were at the top of their game and the story line moved quickly.
The most charming and brilliant love story. You'll want to watch it over and over again. Characters are unforgettable and the scenery is beautiful.

Bill Murray and Bruce Willis in a surprisingly humorous, but serious, look at puppy love.  Two young people decide that they are "in Love", so they decide to run away together.  The only problem is that a serious hurricane is bearing down on the small island where they live.  Murray and Willis are very good in their roles, and the rest of the cast is excellent as well.  A must see, I think, for the whole family.

I had forgotten about Noye's Fludde, delightful music by Benjamin Britten. This movie was very well done & original. I bought it for my professional musician daughter, but her young teenagers enjoyed it more than she did.
Service was good.
not the Tenenbaums, Steve Zissue or even Mr. Fox but a good movie just the same, great style and artistic appeal, glad its on blue ray

Liked it better than the Wizard of Oz.  It is wonderfully funny, sarcastic and silly....Should have won an Oscar. Excellent movie, but only for 13 year old or older.....it is a coming of age movie, love story between two young teenagers on an island of dysfunctional adults, in a unfair world.
Well acted and directed. The actors in unaccustomed roles doing them well. A favorite of ours and our kids too.
Wife and I rented this quirky film about a year ago and loved it. Decided to add it to our small collection of DVDs
Love Wes Anderson and have never been disappointed by one of his movies. Saw this in theaters and immediately pre-ordered this blu-ray. Can't wait to see what Wes creates next.

Best Movie EVER!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I liked it a lot I thad a little bit of everything! It had enough quirkiness, enough sex, enough scariness, enough drugs, enough violence, enough language, enough comedy, and even enough stuff I didn't like!!! I highly recommend this movie to a fourteen year old. It will probably remain my favorite movie EVER!!!! caution, the kids have sex and the girl's MARRIED MOM has a secret relationship with Captain Sharp, the island police!! :( I hope you enjoyed it as much as I did!!!!!!!!!! :D

I saw this movie once before and couldn't wait to get my hands on it. What a great movie and what a great price. I will not be duped into trying Amazon Prime again as I was unaware after my free trial I would be automatically debited and am now struggling with the money I am out waiting for the return, but other than that HAPPY with this purchase

This is a film...not a movie. Now my 2nd favorite Anderson film behind Rushmore. Anyone who knocks this film completely misses the whole point of film as an art form in general or doesn't know of the directors past works. Set in the 60's on a remote coastal community, the story is basically a forbidden love story between two slightly weird 12 year old. Yes its quirky, yes its long, and yes the biggest named actors are not the leads, but the film is pure art, and simply beautiful. Think of your first kiss...and how it was awkward, mysterious, a little scary, and yet completely AMAZING!!! That is this film, so if the world hasn't completely broke you yet, and you still have a little kid inside you somewhere, you cant help but find enjoyment in this film.
  Ive always believed that the point of films are to entertain and take you on an adventure. They either bring you back, take you far away, or expose you to aspects of the world that is foreign to you...and through that, evoke an emotion that will last past the closing credits. A movie, on the other hand, is really just eye candy that is in one ear and out the other, has no redeemable qualities, and evokes no thought or emotion other than basic caveman  s***. The people that trashed this film were obviously looking for a mindless hollywood blockbuster. Art is not for everyone.

...I'd enjoy this one as much as I did.  I've always found this director's movies to be WAY too precious by half.  This one worked, I believe, because of the actors who bought into the vision.  Briefly incongruous and anachronistic but the charm is not diminished.  This is much more "adult" than I expected.  The kids won't be watching this one until they are a little older...
Cute, funny, touching, it's both a chick flick and funny enough for non-chick taste - highly recommended.  makes me smilke just thinking about it

What can I say?  "Moonrise Kingdom" is simply charming, and if you don't get it, you don't get it.  It's not a perfect movie:  Jared Gilman, the boy lead, is uneven (he's best when not speaking), and the themes and execution are a little too close to another Wes Anderson gem, "Rushmore."  But if you can get past that, the movie is well worth your time.  Kara Hayward is sweetly teed off as Suzy, that girl from childhood you always hoped had the potential to grow to independence without instead disappointing you and becoming a self-loving twit, and I don't know that I've ever seen Bruce Willis or Edward Norton in better form.  Bill Murray, Harvey Keitel, Bob Balaban, and Frances McDormand are all used sparingly, and less really is more.  What of the plot?  To describe it here would rob you of the joy of simply experiencing it, but suffice it to say, in an age of ham-fisted garbage like "The Notebook" and "Twilight," it's a refreshing coming-of-age comedy romance for the rest of us, much more "Amelie" than "Titanic," thank goodness.  As a former Boy Scout (yeah, I sometimes have a hard time believing that, too), I'm also stunned at how well the movie captures the oeuvre of just what that means.  Sure, they're called the "Khaki Scouts" here, but there are the same kooky, pseudo-military attitudes mixed in with an aw-shucks saccharine purity -- Anderson steeps his production in such authenticity that I could smell the musty canvas tents again, feel the scratchy cotton of the heavy olive drab shirts.  And it's obvious that he's enjoying what he's doing, creating a movie that has the off-kilter choreography of a puppet show mixed in with a movie's sense of the grand, wrapped up in the dewy remembrances of summers gone by.

Wes Anderson's use of bright colors and alternate realities provides a good escape for the viewer. I recommend this product for anyone who is interested in an aesthetically pleasing cinematic adventure.

All of Wes Anderson's films are excellent, but this one is one of my favorites. As always, it's visually stimulating, has great dialogue, and a strong story. The DVD contains some extras, and behind the scenes footage. It was also nice to see some different actors being used, as opposed to his usual cast (Bill Murray etc.), which I still enjoy.

I liked this movie.  It's a cute young love theme during 1965.  The Khaki Scout, Camp Ivanhoe squad is great and boy scout reminiscent.  My uncle (a Tiger Scout Club Leader) would consider the camp and the Fort as his nemesis.

I liked the photography - beginning I thought the house resembled a doll house and picturesque family, same goes for the scout club.  I thought the plot was good and original.  The acting was very well done.  My favorite characters are Suzy Bishop (Kara Hayward) and Scout Master Randy Ward (Edward Norton).  Suzy was bad a$$ and Randy was a cute dork.

It had it's typical Wes Anderson humor.  I have seen just a a few of his previous works.  I've seen Rushmore, The Royal Tenenbaums and The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou.  Moonrise Kingdom is my favorite now.

I feel as if 28 may be too old to enjoy this movie.  Or perhaps it's my familiarity with Anderson's style.  Either/or, Moonrise Kingdom is more of the same.  Go record Rushmore on TCM and call it a night.

Okay, so you know a Wes Anderson film when you see it. They have a look and a feel. Visually they pop with color. Dialogue is usually clipped and clever and the characters and situations ooze a similar quirkiness. He even managed the same feel in the stop-motion animated "Fantastic Mr. Fox." But these elements can often feel "schticky" and have in many of his movies left me disconnected or disinvested. In short, not taking them very seriously.

Not so with Moonrise Kingdom. Moonrise Kingdom for me is a home run because Mr. Anderson's devices all work here throughout and actually help connect the viewer with the movie. The colors and cinematography work perfectly in telling the story of two angst-filled tweens running away together on a tiny (fictitious) island off the New England coast. The setting is an odd little place with odd little customs and lifestyle so the quirkiness of the characters and situations work naturally.

The performances of the ensemble cast are also spot on and the two new-comers in the lead roles have an endearing chemistry. Mr. Anderson also treats any physicality between the kids with taste and humor and though they are both troubled and have chosen a troubled and hopeless path, you root for them anyway.

Moonrise Kingdom scores for me because it deals with innocent, uncomplicated emotions, in an innocent, uncomplicated setting and delivers its story in a fun, uncomplicated package that is well paced, with a well balanced mix of interesting characters, beautiful locations, clever dialogue and emotions with which we can all identify. As I've said to many who have disagreed with me, "What's not to like?"
But this movie just felt awkward and seemed to drag on when compared to films such as The Life Aquatic and the Royal Tenenbaums

We (my wife & six kids), had a great evening watching this movie.  Our kids have been talking non stop about how much they loved this movie.  This will become one of the movies that we continue to watch at least yearly.  It's a winner!

The premise of this movie is good and the descriptions make it sound quite different than it really is! Star-studded. Yes. But what promised to be an enchanting story became silly and goofy. Too many things were annoying--sailboats that moved like speedboats, floods that weren't really floods, ridiculous and unbelievable people....The young stars and their trajectory was good and touching. Otherwise it was a waste of my time and $$. This seems to be one of those movies that is hyped, only to leave you feeling like a sucker for reviews.
Should have seen this in the theater, but missed it.  something about this movie touched me.  Love all the characters.  Can't wait to watch it again.
Not as good as Rushmore or Royal Tennenbaums in my opinion, but still an interesting film that is a level above most current films.
At the beginning I felt that I made a mistake when I chose to watch this movie; however, I found that it was the best choice that I do. Good play and actors.
I don't k=like many movies.  This is very different, loved, loved, loved.  Highly recommend this to any age.  So cute!

I'm a big fan of "RUSHMORE" and maybe that's where the problem is.  I had seen the trailer for this movie, and I had hoped it was going to be a similar type story, but it's not.  The art direction, camera moves and acting are good, but if the story with its "A" level cast is asked to do things opposite their character type in a rather lack luster story line, then you've got a rather ho-hum movie.

I had heard great reviews about this movie.
It was like The Royal Tannenbalms.  Everyone loved it but me.
It's just not my style, I guess.  Not my sense of humor.
BEST FILM EVER! I love this movie! I watched it about 10 times! BEST FILM EVER! Cool magic creative cute

A tear-jerker it is not but still touching as it plays out young love, very young love. The entire cast is great. Some are cast out of their usual roles, Edward Norton, for instance, which really adds to the flavor of the movie. The exploration of how two "lovers" act and react when isolated are very mature but in a childish way. This is one movie where you will never tire of watching it over and over.

The cast of actors are fantastic & the 2 main teen actors were fabulous in their first professional role. Any person from that era can relate to the "Scouts" & the all around innocence of life. I can rave about the movie enough.
This is a delightful story that is full of interesting characters. It's beautifully filmed and lots of fun to watch.
This is a great story. Period. not a lot of show, not a lot of hype. Just a good, real type story played out by great actors.. It was a fun romp through a coming of age tale.
One of the best movies to come out in a while.  I would recommend this movie to anyone.  End of story.

My girlfriend and I love this film.  The 1st time we rented it, the second time we bought it because we knew we'd want to watch it again and again. If you've seen a film directed by Wes Anderson (The Royal Tenenbaums, The Darjeeling Limited, etc.) you will already be familiar with his directorial style. He has a way of portraying the quirky side of human nature that I have loved in all his films, and this film is his best yet. Mr. Anderson portrays various aspects of each character's internal dialogue without putting the dialogue into words. Each character filters events from within his or her own reality construct coming to completely different and sometimes contradictory or mutually exclusive conclusions about it. It's as if they are in different movies. Often two characters with contradictory interpretations of their lives will be intimately related, or romantically involved.  Mr. Anderson doesn't spell it out literally for the viewer.  Rather, what you're supposed to be getting from a particular scene is implied.  Anderson assumes that the audience will have sufficient intelligence to follow the story.  I like being given the benefit of the doubt. I imagine that while the cast and crew are making the film there is debate about whether the point they are trying to make in a particular scene has been illustrated clearly enough. In this case I think the film wonderfully conveys the unspoken thoughts and feelings of the characters.

To conclude, this film is a keeper.  It's a joy to watch and every time I watch it I notice things that I hadn't seen before.  I know what's going to happen, but I'm still entertained every time I watch it. I cry every time too, but that's one of the reasons I like this film so much.  :-)
Wonderful movie. You can watch it with your children (8 to 14). They will see themselves as the main characters and you will learn a lot about them.
It is quaint and precious....yet not really engaging. Seemed like everyone was trying too hard to be clever....it became tedious to watch....oh well, I appreciate what they were going for.
Plus Bill Murray, Bruce Willis and Frances McDormand are in it, some of my favorite actors. I enjoyed this immensely.
A good well made movie with a great cast about a romantic young couple in love. Never really gets exciting but has a nice constant enjoyable pace to it.

This has to be a classic among films about growing up in the 60s.  If you like classical music you'll certainly love the score.  But even if you don't the movie has a refreshing innocence about it that is so often lacking in films about kids. While the adults, as seen through the eyes of the kids and the audience, are comical in their inability to relate to the kids or each other.  Highly recommended.
I enjoyed watching this and ended up buying a copy of it later on. It has a good story and was interesting to watch.
Do not know what to say.  Good acting, actors in unusual parts for their type, family movie>?  Just a little confused

"Moonrise Kingdom" (2012) is a truly unique comedy-drama that will grow in stature. Director Wes Anderson creates his own cinematic landscape with an offbeat ensemble, brilliant color scheme and eclectic soundtrack. Inexplicably, this quirky masterpiece earned a single Academy Award nomination (Best Original Screenplay). The film deserved more honors than it received.

Good film.  Very off-beat and quirky but quite entertaining.  The cast was amazing- Ed Norton and Bruce Willis were both great.  This was a huge reach for Bruce, and I loved it.  Very endearing story line.
I liked the period of time, a good example of the way things were in 1965.  So different, funny and touching too. I know my daughter and her kids will love it too.

I saw this movie in the theater and wanted to see it again and show it to my husband. It was as lovely a jewel as I remembered. There is a vein of darkness in this tale of growing up. Acting is excellent, design is spare and clean. Like a Cohen Brothers movie for a younger set and adults. Not for children who might be embarrassed at seeing a teenage girl in her underwear.
Had to replace a lost one from the local library.  They have not informed us of any complaints as of yet.
Wes Anderson at his best. Great story, great set design, great characters and all the quirky comedy one comes to expect from Wes Anderson!
It is worthy of being in your collection.  It is suitable for all audiences.  The thought processes shown by the kids will take you back to your youth.  Highly recommend.  A+
Not sure I understood this type of comedy. It had a great cast which was deceiving, but it came across as no one really acting, just acting silly.

This movie is so unique.  I first saw it on HBO and thought wow... I have to buy this!  It's such a fun and quirky movie.  It made me feel like I was a kid again.  The acting is superb and the camera work is very beautiful.  The set design is also just spot on.  If you grew up a boyscout or in the 60's this movie is going to hit home for you.  Highly recommend buying this movie!

... there were 666 five star reviews and I didn't want to misalign the stars.

This is my review:

Moonrise Kingdom is another wonderful Wes Anderson film that, like so many of his other films, contains a few wonderful elements:

- geeky kids
- a cutaway of the characters' living environment
- a wimpy fight sequence near the end
- some sort of natural calamity

Not so sure about the last one, but all of these happen in Moonrise Kingdom, which does its best to re-create Waris Hussein's 1971 puppy love comedy Melody (also known as Sealed With A Loving Kiss), but with his inimical ironic style. Set in rural America in the 1960s, it also has a soundtrack of quirky little musical gems, such as April March's "Les Temps De L'amour", and Benjamin Britten's famous " The Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra (Introduction/Theme; Fugue)", as directed by Leonard Bernstein. A strange young orphan and an odd girl run away from home, get married, and build up a posse of other strange youths, most of them fellow boy scouts, and a sympathetic police captain played by Bruce Willis (?!?!). Harvey Keitel makes a cameo appearance as a grizzled old Scout master, and there's all sorts of bizarre Scout politics involved (John Cusack is a scout leader who, initially disgraced when he loses his squad, who manages to redeem himself). Tilda Swinton is also resplendent as a very serous social worker. A really wonderful film.

I really did.  All strapped in ready for some side-splitting laughs and guffaws and yet these movies (Moonrise Kingdom, The Life Aquatic, Royal Tenebaums) really don't hold a candle to the original Rushmore perhaps due to the era in which they were released (Bush/Obama 2000s vs Clinton 90s).  I know they're not sequels or supposed to be related in an way even though many of the actors are the same.  It's just that as supposed comedies, there's a hell of a lot of down time between laughs, too many serious moments and an emphasis on cleverness and useless information that I just don't need.  These generally aren't funny movies, they're interesting movies, some scenes of which are wonderfully filmed and acted out.  Beautiful scenery, sets, imagination, special effects.  All the films have their humorous moments but for the most part, they seem to rely and focus on life's quirky little oddities, strange coincidences and the "just keep it safe" factor is in full swing, rarely venturing into LOL territory as Rushmore seemed to accomplish at all times.  Bill Murray has done a wonderful job over the past decade (or maybe more) of reprising his role as some kind of manic-depressive, mid-life crisis husband or divorced father of three who can't wait to frown on camera or say something average.  Kids will probably get a kick out of these movies because there is a fantastical, Harry Potter/Finding Nemo feel.
this is a watch with your wife movie...when it's done you can feel slightly amused and not like you've just wasted a bunch of time...good acting..old timey story...i need more popcorn...
An all family classic, shows you the innocence of first love, through the eyes of two kids who dare to be different.

If the movie gods didn't create Wes Anderson somebody would have to.  Never in the history Of Western cinema has there been an individualist like Anderson.  His genteel rebellious streak is unlike any other.  His films feel like a parallel universe with characters much like ourselves who are slightly off kilter.  "Moonrise Kingdom" finds Anderson at his most romantic.  Our protagonists are Sam (Jared Gillman) and Suzy (Kara Hayward) two disaffected adolescents who find each other and run away from unfeeling authority figures to explore the island terrain and their feelings for one another.  Gillman and Hayward are natural and unaffected and at their tender ages can't be faulted for not tapping into the ironies contained in Anderson and Roman Coppola's script.  The ironies, however, are not lost on the adult cast members (Bruce Willis, Edward Norton, Bill Murray, et. al.).  "Moonrise Kingdom" is a piece with Anderson's iconoclastic body of work.  If I could give more than five stars to the film I would.

I went into watching this movie knowing little about it, I'm not sure I ever watched a full trailer, and I like it that way. This movie was such an adventure, it is everything and more I have been wanting in a movie lately. I found myself lying on my stomach, hugging a pillow, and smiling through the entire movie.

QUIRKY. I like quirky movies(Raising Arizona, Hudsucker Proxy, Bringing Up Baby. etc.), but this seemed to put weirdness first and tried to build a story our of it. I had no sympathy for any of the characters and I tend to like counter culture characters (I lived through the 60's and worked in junior high schools for 30 years). This had 40 minutes of my time and that was as far as I could get.

I've been a fan of Wes Anderson's work since I saw Rushmore. It's still one of my favorite films. The Royal Tenenbaums is definitely a close second. When you watch a Wes Anderson movie, you can expect certain things. This movie is very much in those veins and if you like Wes Anderson, you'll probably enjoy this movie as well. It's not my favorite Wes Anderson movie, but I'd rate it higher than Darjeeling Limited or The Life Aquatic.

A great movie which is now in my top ten.

But, I will warn you now:  if you have absolutely no sense of whimsy left inside you, then this movie is not for you.

If you don't already like Wes Anderson movies, this one might not be for you. Like "The Life Aquatic ...," "Moonrise Kingdom" reimagines someone's past and displays it like interactive dioramas. Great fun for the faithful, maybe a bit too precious/stylized for others.

As two 12-year-olds calmly discuss the pros and cons of getting married, beside them a Khaki Scout drops from a two-story platform onto a trampoline, proceeding to turn somersaults as the earnest conversation progresses.  And that, ladies and gents, aptly demonstrates the highly nuanced, charming quirkiness of Wes Anderson's MOONRISE KINGDOM. Until seeing this film I was unaware of this director, but count me in as a fan now.  Anderson can make a film that not only is entertaining, charming, and downright funny--he can create images and sets and combos of colors that are as mesmerizing as they are haunting.

MOONRISE KINGDOM is the story of two tweeners--an orphaned boy (Jared Gilman) who deserts his Khaki Scout troop, and a troubled girl (Kara Hayward) who runs away from home to join him in the wilderness of a New England island in the late summer, as a massive storm approaches.  The pair develops a budding camaraderie and romance (all tastefully done, I might add), and a firm determination to elude the considerable search that's been launched to find them.  Gilman and (especially) Hayward have considerable talent; I look forward to following their acting careers.

Yet MOONRISE KINGDOM is peaked by its stellar ensemble cast, including Edward Norton as a gung-ho Scout Master, Bruce Willis as the island's lone policeman guiding the search, Bill Murray and Frances McDormand as the girl's frightened (yet dysfunctional) parents, Tilda Swinton as a stark, bureaucratic Social Services worker, and Harvey Keitel as a take-no-prisoners Scout Commander.  Special kudos to Bob Balaban, playing the story's deadpanned narrator that constantly had me in stitches.  In fact, if you don't have a grin on your mug from start to finish of the delightfully nuanced MOONRISE KINGDOM, then maybe you just need to lighten up.
--D. Mikels, Esq.

We all loved this movie.  The dialogue is hilariously dead pan, the characters are hard not to love, even if deeply flawed.  The kids loved the adults vs. kids theme and we parents loved the redeeming qualities of the adults in the end, the nostalgia of how it felt to be this age, to run away from home.  One of the best, if quirkiest, movies we've seen in a long time.

imagine a movie that combines the innocence of The Goonies, the honesty of Broadcast News, the absurdity of One Hot American Summer, and the purity of Harold and Maude and you get one of the most beautiful films I have ever seen.  While I anticipate all his future endeavors, this film will forever resonate as his definitive work, in my book. Thank you, Wes!

just finished watching Wes Anderson's Moonrise Kingdom, which is, hands down, one of the most whimsical, magical films I've encountered in many moons. An Anderson fan, I hesitated to see this when it was released as mixed reviews (which usually happens in Anderson films anyway) many discounting it as "a series of poses and postures" often singling out the "awful" acting of the two leads discouraged me. Well, I was a silly goose, and those critics, as earnest as they may have been, couldn't have been more wrong in describing this thing if they'd tried.

The leading couple, Sam (Jared Gilman) and Suzy (Kara Hayward) are a pair of emotionally challenged 12 year olds who fall in love during a performance of Britten's Noye's Fludde. I couldn't imagine either role cast better than here, nor more nuanced performances coaxed by a director who actually "gets" kids - particularly troubled ones. The story begins when Sam, a highly decorated, though not well liked cadet Sam flees the confines of Camp Ivanhoe and his Khaki Troop (think Boy Scouts of America) to run away with unpredictable and misunderstood Suzy. Their inventory for survival includes a kitten in a basket (with accompanying cans of gourmet cat food), a battery operated record player and a suitcase full of stolen library books. My kind of kids. Living on a remote island (about to be hit by the storm of the century) they can't really escape far . . . or can they? Through (several) ensuing chases, unsuccessful captures, and re-escapes the story grows exponentially, layer by layer as it introduces us to the foibles, quirks and ticks of the residents as our Island Romeo and Juliet explore their burgeoning sexuality (all tastefully within the confines of its PG-13 rating).

Speaking of Noye's Fludde, Anderson had me from the start, as any movie that bookends its opening and closing scenes with Britten's Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra, has already got plenty going for it! And Britten's music (in addition to large chunks of Noye) looms large throughout, as does that of Schubert (An die Musick), Mozart (Cosi's Soave sia il vento) Saint Sans (Carnival of the Animals) and Hank Williams. So, too, does the score by composer Alexandre Desplat who pays tribute to Britten (remarkably directly in the closing credits, where his own "Guide to the Orchestra" is narrated by the film's hero).  Rarely does one find film music these days that is this integrally bound to the storytelling that it's virtually impossible to imagine the story without it.

Anderson sets his tale circa 1965 on the fictional New England island of New Penzance. The nod to Gilbert and Sullivan is here more dramatic than musical, but nonetheless unmistakable. The parallels between Moonrise's young Sam, and Pirates' Frederic are plentiful. While entirely original, Moonrise nonetheless feels punctuated throughout as it evokes gauze-covered memories of other things. It was constantly conjuring fleeting instances causing my mind to race to discover connections between it and Romeo and Juliet, The Tempest, The Keystone Cops, Lord of the Flies, and more. Robert D. Yeoman's remarkably nuanced cinematography makes every frame look like a page from an old family photo album, capturing summer camp, skinned knees and emotional secrets barely covered through veils of thin smiles. Moonrise Kingdom, indeed.

Though Sam and Suzy are the heart of the film, Moonrise is truly an ensemble piece and Anderson is able to evoke marvelous, sometimes larger than life, performances from an inspired cast of Bruce Willis, Edward Norton, Bill Murray, Frances McDormand, Tilda Swinton, Jason Schwartzman, Harvey Keitel and Bob Baliban (who serves as narrator/Greek Chorus), and all of whom create the believable, quirky, characters who populate this magical island town.

In my estimation critics who found this "stifling" simply are never going to like films made by the likes of Mr. Anderson, directors who essentially eschew The Hollywood Way, as they put out beautiful, boutique films for small audiences willing (or wishing) to escape into the fantastic worlds they've created for us. For those not willing to do so, I suppose these films really can be, as one critic described Moonrise "a long, dull exercise in alternative comedy." For the rest of us . . . it's a dream.

I would have given this three stars as a good offbeat, quirky movie, but the portrayal of sexuality and marriage between barely developed 12-year-olds was disturbing. I'm surprised more reviewers weren't troubled by that.

Edward Norton in his most benign and unbelievable (?) scout leader role, Bill Murray is perfect as the philosophizing psychologist who is a terrible parent. Odd little story about a runaway boy scout who teams up with a runaway girl, both pursued by their families and the scout troop, it is a "relationship movie" between the two youngsters on a PG level. A nice subplot involves Bruce Willis and Francis McDormand (the island cop and Murray's wife, mother of the missing girl), who are romantically involved.
Everything is about sweetness, details, colors, music, childhood feelings, love, humanity. I watch it so many times ! I love this movie

Oddly, in a movie where your emotions should be vested in what happens to two misfit runaway kids, in "Moonrise Kingdom," you just don't care.  The problem is that none of the characters connect emotionally in the film. The dialogue is delivered in a robotic, deadpan way throughout, such that what you get is dialogue trying to sound cutesy but without any real emotional connection to the people who are actually delivering the dialogue.  It's almost like robot-speak.  This becomes tedious, affected and deadening, and unfortunately the script is far less eccentric or humorous than it would seem to believe itself to be.  Here's about as close to any real bond as we get between the runaway boy and girl, starting with the girl: "It feels hard." "Do you mind?" "I like it." "You can touch my chest.  I think they're gonna grow more." I mean, is this for real?  It sounds like Alvin and the Chipmunks by way of David Mamet.  Even as the movie spins out of control at the end, which is all too predictable, you don't really care about any of these characters.

I had been getting bored with Wes Anderson's flicks. You have daddy issues; I get it. But when they killed that dog...holy smoke. Sold. I hate dogs, and killing one on screen made my day. Best part of the film. I know it was fake, and no animals were harmed, blah blah blah, but even the fake dog killing made my day. Always barking, #2ing wherever; 'bout time someone whacked one. Let this be a lesson to all dogs and dog owners.

The audiences enjoyment of Moonrise Kingdom really depends on their like for Wes Anderson movies. If only one thing can be said about Wes Anderson its that he definitely has his own style. Anderson movies are usually slower paced in oddly detailed environments with intelligent dialogue and a sense of comedy that is exceptionally dry. Moonrise Kingdom is no exception to these conventions, however it falls short because all of the oddities don't amount to anything of particular interest this time.

Moonrise Kingdom is a love story between children. Sam (Jared Gilman) is a Khaki Scout who leaves the organization to run away with a local girl, Suzy (Kara Hayward). When his escape is discovered by Scout Master Ward (Edward Norton) an investigation is started involving the rest of the scouts and the Captain of the local police, Captain Sharp (Bruce Willis). Bill Murray and Frances McDormand are the Bishops, Suzys parents. The two are very confrontational and constantly get in the way of the search for the run away kids. There is never a sense of danger for the movie, thats not what Moonrise Kingdom is about. It is a quirky love story set in a real enough era but with a surreal twist.

The movie never ramps up enough that the audience is on the edge of their seat about anything. There is no question about the progression of the movie or the end results. Even when new elements are introduced to the audience it is clear where things are going to end up.

Moonrise Kingdom boasts a very solid cast but no breakout performances. Gilman and Hayward are solid child actors but the deadpan delivery that comes with Anderson movies may be the cause for that. Bill Murray is a staple in Anderson movies and usually provides a good amount of the offbeat humor. In Kingdom he is more a placeholder than anything. Frances McDormand has never been a great actress, she got lucky with Fargo and that is the sole reason she continues to receive acting work. Edward Norton was probably the funniest performance of the movie. Norton is usually an edgy and very serious actor but in Kingdom he plays the complete opposite.

Unfortunately the movie lacked substance so there isn't much more to say. Its one of Andersons weaker movies. In a year filled with amazing performances, break out stars, and truly original movies it is a complete mystery how Moonrise Kingdom got nominated for an Academy Award at all.
I really wanted to like this movie, but for some reason it just didn't keep my attention, even with the great actors.
I'm a big Wes Anderson fan!  I had very high expectations of this movie and they were more then met!

I love movies that show the kids to be smarter than the adults. I love most everything by Wes Anderson, who always seems to find a scenario that delights and make one think. How he comes up with these ideas is a wonder, and he never fails to amuse. (The Oscar nom for screenplay attests to that.)

The use of color, and that little element of fantasy is something I always look forward to in a Wes Anderson film. The BluRay does not disappoint. Glad to have it to watch after a disappointing day. A true upper for the senses.

very strange and very funny.  helps to have grown up at the same time as the feel of the early 60s is very much in control of the action and some younger viewers might not get all the humor or context.
The entire movie is shot like a 1960s classic with sepia tones and a quirky story. I really loved it. The character development was very rich.
Silly and a bit off beat but what else would you expect from this cast? Love that it is different and not sure where it is going.

Ok, I will try.  Quirky funny characters, loveable characters, hateable characters, flawed but trying characters...beautifully written and played parts in this movie.

The story line is hilarious and beautiful.  I would say it's the best of all the films by this director.

And I cannot say enough about the stars in this.  They did not play their parts like movie stars...as you watch, you forget it is them, they are raw and vulnerable and endearing for who they are in these 2 hours.
Bill Murray and Bruce Willis together and yet neither of them steals the show from the great kid actors. Fabulous photography, in my view this move is true art.
If you like Wes, you won't be disappointed by this.  Sometimes his films seem to lack compelling story lines, but not this.  After watching it, I am back to revisiting his earlier titles.

The cast in this alone makes it worth getting.

The color palette is truly remarkable: Wes Anderson clearly went to a lot of trouble to make everything look right.  The story is fun and acting marvelous.
A quirky film but quite engaging. In addition to the excellent  acting, pay  attention to the colors. Good music too.

The cast is fantastic and must have had a great time working together. The newcomers, the young leads, were just perfect and deserved an oscar nod along side the "Beasts of the Sothern Wild" girl. This film will make you laugh, and you never know which way it is going. I highly recommend it ............. don't let this slip away. It will capture your heart and when it is over - you will say " Gee, that was a great small movie with a big heart " - kind of magical and definitely worth seeing - even if just for Edwatd Norton's boy scout uniform. my daughter wanted this movie...it came quickly and the price was less then in local box stores...we all enjoyed it!

I about fell out when Edward Norton first walked out of his tent in his spiffy little shorts. Quite a change from previous roles.

This is one of those movies that is slightly off-kilter, but highly entertaining.  The movie is downright funny, and every actor delivers without being over-the-top.  Bill Murray, Ed Norton, Bruce Willis and Francis McDormand are excellent, but the kids own the movie.  This is one you will be glad you bought.

I already knew I loved this movie before I bought it... I'd see. It in theaters and knew that I'd be adding it to my DVD collection before the film was even halfway through. However, after reading articles and seeing interviews with the two young stars of the film, I was so impressed to find that this film was their acting debut. To keep pace with the well-known veteran actors without any prior experience really highlights their talents.

As for the rest of the film, it's a simple tale of young, impetuous love... And all of the hilarity and heartache that goes with it.
With the great names of the cast I could have done with out the supporting cast.  The two main charactors were great!!
Got sucked into this moving per my wife's recommendation.  Initially, it seemed a bit slow, but it grew on me as the movie progresses.  I ended up liking it.

This was a delightful movie in so many ways. I loved everything from the almost surreal "colorization" of the film quality to the quirky characters and the hilarious reminders of what life was like growing up in the 1960s.  (unsupervised childhoods, the way professions that required uniforms ("Social Services") always included a pillbox hat, etc.)  I loved the character development and the subtle humor (references to "Sunday-school shoes" and "lefty-scissors").  The Bruce Willis character of the island policeman and the Scout Leader are both especially well developed. I enjoyed the movie so much I watched it three times.  The only reason I don't give it five stars is that I reserve that hallowed rating for my lifetime favorite movies, and this movie was not deep enough for that.  But this is a fun and extremely enjoyable movie -- at least for Baby Boomers like myself who enjoy remembering how our childhoods were very free in some ways -- we jumped off of roofs onto trampolines with no net and no supervision, and we never had pre-arranged "play-dates," and yet we lived under the threat of things like the uniformed Miss "Social Services," who loomed in the Orwellian background of Cold War childhoods.  When you watch this movie, you will both chuckle at the accurate capture of the 1960s and sigh for the loss of that world with its goofy innocence.

A time period set adolescent love story that avoids tawdry voyeurism and shows a better way to be for all of America's teens.  This film has tones from 50's and 60's Disney films without the stupid naivete.  The cast is amazing as they embrace Mr. Anderson's wonderul vision of what it is to fall in love as a young person entering a new world.

Moonrise Kingdom was a very enjoyable movie with a great cast.  I found Edward Norton preformance great for the character he was doing, along with Bruce Willis being a human being slash police officer and watching out for the boy so nothing bad would happen to the kid.  As for the movie itself I found myself laughing at mutiple scenes, remebering for me its was a middle school crush but not love.  But I could defently relate to the young love concept for the boy and girl in the movie.  I gave this movie a four star rating out of five because parts of the movie had me going you got to be kidding me, but overall a very amazing movie with a heartfelt message about a person's first love and what you would do to be with that first love. Plus at times I find myself wondering what happened to that part of my life, this movie and movies like it help me hold onto that part of my life and never forget the kid inside me.

The film takes place in 1965 on an idyllic New England island, New Penzance, bringing together two semi-nerds. Sam Shakusky is at a 'Khaki Scout' summer camp, and Suzy Bishop lives on the island with her attorney parents. The two had met the previous summer and had been pen pals since, making a secret pact to run away together. Sam brings camping equipment, Suzy takes six books, her cat, and a record player.

Turns out Sam's an orphan and his foster parents don't want anymore of him after hearing of his latest escapade. Sam and Suzy's future together looks dark, despite their 'getting married,' until police commander Sam Sharp gets involved.

What a great movie.  What fun. too bad the mainstream movie goer only wnats sex and violence. this film has plot and acting. sit down with a big bowl of popcorn and enjoy the movie

Not at all the light-hearted comedy we expected from the promos.  Disturbing...kids stabbing kids, a dog gets shot with an arrow, packs of scouts acting blood-thirsty.  Just not well-written, either.  Too many odd, pointless story lines muddy up the script, like adults having affairs with each other and another scout camp that appears out of no where, like a second thought.  And the stars aren't novel or eclectic, they're just violently disturbed or depressed children.  Editing, lighting, filming...even the idea of the narration were excellent.  Just a bad story based on a good idea that tries too hard to be deep and meaningful.

I give it 5 stars because of the quality of the film over all and its story telling.

Wes Anderson has a very unique style that for some, could be hard to get.  The cast in this film is just plain amazing and really bring it to life in this touching tale of two kids falling in love and all the dysfunctional adults trying to put an end to their dream life.  There is a strange feeling that the very unreal characters are so very real.  The film suspends you in a state of unreality that just allows you to let go while watching and kind of forget how uninteresting our own lives can be while you follow these very obscure people down their rabbit holes.

Overall,  touching, sad, raw, and hilariously sarcastic tones permeate the movie.  The characters are so quirky but believable that you find yourself saying "did they really just say that?"

Once again,
Bravo Wes Anderson

The story is about young love on a grand, even epic scale. All the witty dialogue you've come to expect from Wes is in full force, but it is also deeply moving. When the credits rolled by the first time I watched it, I wanted to cry, laugh, cheer, and clap all at once.

I really liked this movie. It was different, fun, and eccentric. I loved how it was shot also. The colors were great. The acting was superb! What a great cast, all the way down to the little boys. Definitely a must watch!

I'm a big fan of director Wes Anderson, but hated his last live-action effort the Darjeeling Limited.  His films have always been offbeat and quirky, but I was afraid he was becoming a caricature of himself.

Thankfully, he returns to top form with Moonrise Kingdom.  This is one of his best.  The film, of course, has usual Andersonian quirkiness, but the story is solid and provides laughs and touching dramatic moments.  Unlike Darjeeling, this film has a stronger plot and doesn't get lost in its own style.  The quirks and details enhance the story, instead of being the main attraction.

The cast is also star-studded and each actor, both stars and unknowns, deliver phenomenal performances.  Check this one out!

***1/2

Highly original in both concept and style -as is customary with any Wes Anderson production - "Moonrise Kingdom" nevertheless proves that, even in the most skillful of hands, a little quirkiness can go a long way.

Set in 1965, this surrealistic indie comedy focuses on two misfit children - one a twelve-year-old orphan and the other the daughter of two whacked-out parents - who run off to a remote New England island so they can live in isolation with one another, right as a hurricane is about to hit the area.

The talented Jared Gilman and Kara Haywood play the two social outcasts, while the adults are portrayed by Bill Murray, Frances McDormand, Edward Norton, Bruce Willis, Tilda Swinton, Jason Schwartzman and Harvey Keitel as an assortment of parents, troop leaders, detectives and social services officials. The irony is that most of the adults turn out to be even more bizarre and dysfunctional than the children who've run away because they just don't fit in.

Co-written  by Roman Coppola and Wes  Anderson and directed by Anderson, "Moonrise Kingdom" is overflowing with wit, striking imagery and on-the-mark deadpan performances. But the archness does get to be a bit much at times, and the atonal, emotionless line readings eventually take their toll on the audience.

It's a clever and likable enough little trifle that, even at a relatively brief 94-minute running time, winds up overstaying its welcome. But the critics sure seem to love it.

Young love always plays out in mysterious ways. We always try to let authority not to come between each other. For two preteen lovers, their love will create a fireball of drama for a peaceful island. I've seen many of Wes Anderson's films and they've truly been enjoyable, but "Moonrise Kingdom" is definitely a one of a kind romance that would be impossible to recreate.

The film takes place on a small New England island in 1965. We see some of the island's sights and landmarks that makes it so somberly. The story starts when one morning, a Khaki Scout troop leader (Edward Norton) discovers that one of his scouts has gone AWOL. So with the help of his entire troop and the local sheriff (Bruce Willis), they're going to find him by any means necessary.

Later, we find our runaway boy named Sam (Jared Gilman), who is secretly meeting Suzy (Kara Hayward), the girl he's been infatuated since they first met a year ago and have been communicating in letters since. They had made a pact to meet each other and their relationship starts to become more deeper. The two make their way through rocky hills, pine tree forests, and the more they're together, the more their love grows.

Meanwhile, the residents of the island go on a wild goose chase to find the two lovers. When Sara's parents (Bill Murray, Frances McDormand) hear about her disappearance, they are more than shocked about it. But they discover that the island people are looking, Sam and Suzy are determined to outplay they, no matter what the consequences are.

If you're expecting a sappy lovey-dovey teen romance, well forget it. This romance is just so unbelievable and so genuine that you'll be aching to see what's next. The cast is very superb, with Gilman and Hayward that won me over, as well as small roles by Jason Schwartzman and Tilda Swinton. There are a few moments in the film that will surprise you, as well as you laugh a bit. Wes Anderson fans will call this his best, while others will call it so-so. For me, it's a romance I wouldn't mind seeing over and over again.

Final Verdict: Anderson's take on a young love story is truly an incredible and unexpected prize.
love it!! great fun for all ages. love the setting, made me feel like i would like to visit the island the movie was filmed.

Edward Norton as the scout master is the best of the picture, but the two child leads at the films head do not disappoint in any moment they are on screen. Everything from the music to the costumes is something to relish and adore! Moonrise is a sure-fire win. One of the best films of 2012, if not the most fun.
