("The Addams Family" did much the same, but did it better).  It's a story that could be told in the present tense, but they decided to use the sixties and did well enough by it.  Yet, for me, the film didn't deliver..  I liked the "Royal Tennenbaums", and "The Life Aquatic", but "Moonrise Kingdom" didn't seem to make its story interesting enough to make me want to care about the characters.  The title didn't help, "Moonrise Kingdom" suggests much more fantasy than the film offered.  Certainly the buzz was overdone, and affected my experience.

Fortunately, you can watch the DVD for a lot less money, without all the in-theater commercials, and you may well find it amusing.  It's not a bad film by any measure, I just don't think it''s nearly as good as the Media  insisted.

Even if you're not a huge Wes Anderson fan, even if you've never see any of his other movies, you'll still enjoy this movie. I promise you that. And as someone who is a huge Wes fan, this might just be my favorite work he's done.

With Wes Anderson, you either buy into his odd, very idiosyncratic and distinctive style, with it's touches of
twisted, surreal fairy-tale tone, and performances that are both restrained on yet not at all naturalistic -
or you don't. For me, I find his style almost always endearing, and both very funny and very touching (The
Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou was the one time it didn't really work for me).

As always the performances here are remarkable from Bruce Willis, Edward Norton, Bill Murray (the quintessential
Wes Anderson actor), Francis McDormand and Tilda Swinton as the adults, to two luminous and unique
performances by the film's pre-adolescent lovers Kara Haywood and Jared Gilman.

While imposing a seemingly astringent style, all right angles (almost every cut within a scene is at 90 degrees or
180 degrees to the shot before it), and carefully composed tableaux, this film captures the wonderful, surreal
weirdness of first love (or at least one's childhood fantasy of first love) with a moving and hilarious honesty.

Somehow, while the story of Sam and Suzy's attempt to escape from the insane adult world that surrounds them
has little to do with the realities of day to day life as we know it, it has everything to do with the realities of the
budding heart.

I can't remember when a film so reminded me of my own first fantasies of love and (tasteful but honest) sexuality.
I love when a film makes a tear fall from my eye at the same time I'm laughing, and that's the rare trick Anderson
has accomplished here.

This a singular Anderson achievement which outdistances his unique body of prior work both by stepping more out into the real world.  The characters and music merge seamlessly with a plot on the surface humorous and entertaining but on reflection thought provoking as well--one of the few movies I have seen in a long time that I have thought about for a long time afterwards and actually look forward to seeing again.  There are really two movies going on at once.  On first viewing, you see the outward moving by focusing on the story and action of the main players; but behind that, as is true of all Anerson films, there is a literally a background plot most of which is missed unless you ignore what is going on in front in order to see behind.  The movie has its strange points, Suzy with the bloody scissors after fending off the scout attackers and Sam's nonchalant reply that it was either them or us, the lighting hit on Sam near the end, and the chaotic final scenes when the storm hits.  I think one of the most poignant moments is when Willis agrees to adopt Sam to save him from Social Services and before agreeing Sam looks to Suzy for her approval--a look that speaks volumes of the depth of their relationship.  A superb cast all around but in my view Suzy steals the show.  Best move I've seen as long as I can remember.

Wes Anderson has created a quirky comedy that is sure to appeal to people of high intelligence, but which might elude those who feast on slapstick comedy alone.  The child actors in this movie are uniformly terrific, as are all the adults.  The movie looks like a Norman Rockwell painting come to life, but with a twist of Salvador Dali thrown in.  There are laughs aplenty, from the parents who refuse to take their foster child back, to the Khaki Scout troop members who are featured prominently.  Edward Norton deserves lots of praise for his performance as the scout master, but the real star is director and writer, Mr. Anderson.

I enjoyed this more than any other Anderson film I've seen.

Wes Anderson is a true singularity. I suppose I aught to be amazed he manages to get green lights on his projects but I'm glad he does. This film is no exception. It is one of the most wonderfully weird flicks I've ever seen.

Here's the scoop. Sam is an outsider in his scout troop. Suzy is an outsider in her home. The two meet, fall in love, and head for the road. The rest of the troop, the family and the local police band together to find the lovers.

It's difficult to convey how entirely odd this film is. The characters, the sets, the story are all goofy beyond belief. But somehow it not only works, it makes its own sense. And all the actors seemed to get it. They all played their roles to a "T." Even Bruce Willis (this is not his usual fare) worked his part and made it happen. Now, to be fair, there were some heavy guns here. Ed Norton, Bill Murray, Frances McDormand, to name a few, are all veterans, so that should be a given. But the two kids are first timers and they managed their roles beautifully as well.

The film is gorgeous. The opening doll house-like scenes, with their clean lines and primary colors, made me wonder (until I saw the moving bodies) if I were watching an actual set or some bizarre special effect. The outdoor scenes (this is set on an Island off New Hampshire) were idyllically filmed. I wanted to be there. The music score/sound track was great as well.

There is nothing in this movie I didn't like. It reminded me how versatile the medium can be, and how it can fill an audience with a sense of wonder. I don't know if I would want to meet a person who didn't like it, because it would make me think that something inside of them has died.

This film was amazing, the cast is superb and the story is completely engrossing. Unlike many films that attempt to delve into the awkwardness of adolescent first loves, Wes Anderson yet again blasts one out of the park, making you feel like a confused love sick teen all over again.  One of the best movies I have seen in years. Another very note worthy aspect of 'Moonrise Kingdom' is that the two child stars are the age they play in the film, no early 20's kids pretending to be young. That being said for two thirteen year olds to act so well was astounding. This film is a must see/must own.
As I was leaving the theater I promised myself to see it again. It was that good. That was a week ago.  Now I'm thinking I'm going to buy the DVD.  Wes Anderson get's it.

Who doesn't remember their first crush, when the first pangs of pre-adolescent loneliness and confusion resolve into the possibility of everlasting happiness? Director Wes Anderson's "Moonrise Kingdom" gives us his typically-tilted take on young love. Sam Shakusky (Jared Gilman) plays a scout troop reject who, early in the film, decamps from the spit-and-polish Maine island campsite run by his super-efficient troop leader (Ed Norton). Sam sets off alone, decked in Davy Crockett-style coonskin cap and armed with an air rifle, determined to rendezvous with his true love. The object of his affections, Suzy Bishop (Kara Hayward), is another disaffected 12-year-old who lives in lonely ennui with her doofus attorney parents, (Bill Murray and Frances McDormand) and her three, goofy classical-music-crazed young brothers. Suzy scans the horizon with her binoculars, obviously looking for something, or someone, to take her away from her boredom and problems. Soon, the pair of misfits has joined forces, and set off on a forest adventure while parents, fellow scouts and the island police (Bruce Willis) join in the search.

I'm not usually a big Wes Andersen fan, but I found this film irresistible. Partly, because of the film's sometimes-cloudy plotline. Suzy's parents treat her adolescent poutiness as a sign of emotional disturbance, making them even more distant to her. Sam, too, comes from a tragic beginnings. He is a peculiar and nerdy kid (like an old college prof, he smoke a small corncob pipe filled with god-knows-what) but is essentially harmless. Sam and Suzy Set up camp in an isolated inlet, and express their love in mostly innocent ways - dancing, talking, reading to each other. Soon, we learn that her pursuers have problems of their own. Suzy's parents are having marriage problems, and the adults on the island seems to have settled for lives of quiet desperation. The search for Sam and Suzy is the shakeup that everyone needs to (maybe) shuck off old habits and take a new tack.

Andersen's film, set in 1965 (though with a 1955 mindset) is shot in the pale hues of fade photographs. His signature cutaway houses make an appearance, as does the stilted, mannered acting style he directs onto the cast. He riffs lovingly on scouting and church theater. But what makes this film tolerable (and what was missing from the unbearable "The Undersea World of Steven Zisou") is the suffering at the core of the silliness. Suzy, Sam and the gang really are desperate for love. And it's a testament to Andersen's creative heart that he is able to hold the cute humor in check long enough to take their quest seriously.

Moonrise Kingdom is the magical seventh film by Wes Anderson. It's undeniable that Anderson has carved a niche for himself, making highly evocative films that treat each frame as a canvas and tell the story with a perfect amount of wry humor and minimalism, but I've always had a love/hate relationship with his films. While I always admire his style and the unique vision he brings to every project, out of his previous six films I've loved only three. His skill as a director aside, he's a terrific writer with a great feel for character, a dry sense of humor, and a great penchant for subtlety. My gripes with him only arise when his style completely overrides substance and his film becomes a stylistic exercise in monotony. Thankfully, this is not the case with Moonrise Kingdom, the best film I've seen this year. It's too soon to say (and his greatest admirers may call it heresy), but this may be my favorite Wes Anderson film.

The film takes place in 1965 on an idyllic island called New Penzance. The story centers around two young children, Sam Shakusky and Suzy Bishop (Jared Gilman and Kara Hayward, making their film debuts). Sam is an orphan attending a Khaki Scout summer camp on the island led by Scout Master Ward (Edward Norton). Suzy is staying on the island with her dysfunctional parents Walt and Laura Bishop (Bill Murray and Frances McDormand) and her three young brothers. Both are troubled, awkward social outcasts who met the previous summer and remained pen pals, ultimately agreeing to run away together on the island. This prompts a search posse for the two, led by Captain Sharp (Bruce Willis). As is characteristic of Anderson's work, the adults in the story are just as dyspeptic as the children, if not more so.

For me, Moonrise Kingdom is the summation of the cinematic techniques, stylistic vision, and depth of character that Anderson has honed in his previous films. He doesn't depart far from his formula in Moonrise Kingdom, but he puts all of his strengths on display and produces an adroit work of art that resonates on an emotional and visual level. With a directorial style that's so infused into the DNA of his films you can often identify his work by a single frame. He keeps his work from growing repetitious by expanding on and refining his talents; as a result, this may be his most beautiful film. A cynosure due to his impeccable use of a color palette that is rustic, vivid, and nostalgic, but never garish. He's worked with cinematographer Robert Yeoman since his debut Bottle Rocket and Yeoman's camera work has never more clearly had such a confident grasp on Anderson's visual aesthetic. Every frame looks like a great photograph. It's not only beautiful but atmospheric, particularly in the way it evokes the chimerical 1960s that exists in Anderson's head. Anderson is a master of style and setting, but is even more masterfully adept at using music to complement mood, style, and setting. Both the original compositions and time-specific music are essential to the spell this film casts.

I've never questioned Anderson's ability to create a beautiful cinematic canvas, but what elevates Moonrise Kingdom is the script he co-wrote with Roman Coppola. It has the substance and the beauty necessary to validate the style. With style and substance working together in perfect harmony, he weaves a fairy tale tapestry of magical realism and whimsy that's effortlessly charming and likable. It helps that he never seems preoccupied with things going on outside the realm of his own creations. There's never the impression that anyone else on the island exists except for those directly involved in the mechanics of the plot. Keeping the focus solely on these characters gives them very distinct personalities and attributes. His characters are often quirky, reserved, and poetic, but they never feel rehashed from previous creations. What makes Moonrise Kingdom so heartfelt and poignant is that it's essentially a love story between two pre-teen children and it takes these characters seriously. By treating them with respect rather than as a foil, he captures the innocence and purity of young love in a way that's rarely captured so effectively and beautifully. I imagine he admires the lack of pretense that exists in these children, especially in relation to the story's dysfunctional adults that go through similar trials and reveal themselves as the more nave personalities.

Anderson never falters on casting wrong and he pulls frequently from a troupe of actors well-versed in the rhythm of his films. There are familiar faces here; Jason Schwartzman, and of course Bill Murray, both of whom seem perfectly at home here. Bruce Willis gives one of his best performances in years; a succinct, quiet role that reminds us of his ability to go beyond "action star" when given the right material. Norton takes to Anderson's world natural, giving a quirky, alacritous performance as the timid Scout Master. Moonrise Kingdom is very funny, but in the most subtle way, never pining for laughs or acknowledging that something a character has said was supposed to be funny. Anderson really pulls great work from the two newcomers, Gilman and Hayward. They're both the same age as the characters they play and they bring that nave, yet perceptive quality that Hollywood films so often fail to capture by casting grown men and women as young people. The entire cast does great work and fit this grand puzzle perfectly.

Moonrise Kingdom is an astonishing accomplishment that envelops you in its warm symmetry and entrances you in its spell. It's a light, funny, and feel-good film that I can't imagine viewers being able to easily disregard. In the coming months, it'll certainly remain one of the year's best films. It panders to the visual and auditory senses, but plays just as strongly on emotional and thoughtful level. Wes Anderson has really outdone himself as a filmmaker and his latest effort is a work of undeniable beauty and artistry.

Wes Andersen remains in a place apart as far as contemporary directors are concerned. Last we heard from him, he brought us "Fantastic Mr. Fox", a delightful stop-motion movie of all things. Now three years later, Anderson returns with this.

"Moonrise Kingdom" (94 min.) brings the story of 12 year olds Suzy and Sam, who have run away (she: from home; he: from scouts camp) on an idyllic island in the northeast in the summer of 1965. That is the starting premise of the movie, and to tell more would ruin your viewing pleasure. Several comments and observations: this movie captures a lot of things, but clearly tugs at the hearts of those who grew up in that era, now almost 50 years ago. It was a completely different world, where communication was not instant and not omni-present. In that sense, the movie is very nostalgic indeed. Second, the visuals of the movie are outstanding. Lots of brown and orange are filtered into the scenery, making it look even more idyllic that it already is. Third, the acting here is mostly superb, with lots of juicy performances from Bruce Willis (his best in years), Bill Murray, Frances McDormand, and even Tilda Swinton and Harvey Keitel in short cameos (Swinton as the Social Worker, and Keitel as Commander Pierce).

But the jewel piece in the movie goes to the 12 year old actors, Jared Gilman as Sam and even more so Kara Hayward as Suzie. She is simply amazing. I enjoyed this movie immensely. It is funny, poignant, and whimsical at its very best. I read that this movie was made on a $16 million dollar budget, which is less than 1/10th of many of the current blockbuster movies. It's amazing how much more can be achieved with so much less. If you are in the mood for an outstanding indie movie, "Moonrise Kingdom" is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

Just in from seeing Moonrise kingdom in theaters and I loved it. As all Wes Anderson movies it is very smart, fast and funny. I really enjoyed each character and all the actors really put a lot into their performance.

Of Wes Anderson's films I would say The Life Aquatic and the Royal Tenenbaums are my favorite. Moonrise Kingdom would be next. I liked the younger cast as they really put a different spin on the story, as even with adult themes they pulled it off with tastefulness. There also is an interesting link between the adults and the children as each of there interactions are mirrored in the others story.

It is a very solid movie, well written and very well directed. Wes is at the top of his game. The soundtrack was also outstanding, as it is in most of his films.

Highly recommended.

Two young people run away together and are pursued by scout leaders and police. The boy and girl are in love and set out on an unusual journey to be together. This clever comedy has quite a few talented actors in it, and while not laugh-out-loud funny, it does have some witty moments and the film is enhanced by the talent within. I found myself enjoying the journey of these two misfit children who have each found their soul mate, and at times appear to be beyond their years. Overall, this is a smart, funny, well-made comedy that will keep you rooting for the two young people.

IN A WORLD WHERE films must shock, where films must employ impossible stunts, extreme violence and outrageous characters, comes Moonrise Kingdom - with none of it. This is a real STORY, with real characters, in which everything that happens is actually possible. What a concept. Told with humor and compassion, the film sweeps you along without the dreaded need for suspension of disbelief. The story is pure Americana - life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness. Some do it better than others. Not everyone is a winner. Its stars - seven of them! - are all totally out of character. This is not a Bill Murray vehicle or an Edward Norton vehicle or a Bruce Willis vehicle. The stars fit in, almost as afterthoughts. It's the story that counts. Most impressively, it has style. From the opening shots of Susie, face on with her binoculars in various rooms of the house, you know this film will be stylish. And understated. It is worthy of any screen in the world, in a world where American films have become overpoweringly boring and repetitive and entirely predictable. This is the kind of film that France would have originated, and which Americans would have remade into a noxious overkill of action and adventure. It is therefore rare and precious. It will endure long after Transformers XXVII has faded. Kudos to Wes Anderson and team for resisting the urges that every other Hollywood production takes for a granted as a requirement. Bob Balaban as the narrator, making his own appearance in the story, is inspired, as is his framing in the shots. That kind of attention to style gives Moonrise Kingdom the ability to sweep you away. On these shores, this is the first must see in years.

This is the Ideal Perfect Summer Movie

The miracle of this movie is that it not only offers a glimpse/reminder of what it was like to be young without idealizing youth (aren't all young people unsatisfied customers) but it also offers a glimpse of what it feels like being old (still an unsatisfied customer). And yet Wes Anderson films suggest (and this one better than any of the others) that we can find comraderie/community and, yes, even love, by simply sharing our dissatisfactions with another.

The island community puts on a play every year about Noah's flood, and in Wes Anderson's version of this Bible story the only way to survive the rising tide of youthful/adult dissatisfaction is in twos.

Moonrise Kingdom has the power of an allegorical fable and the sheer visual delight of a toy store/amusement park fantasyland. No other director is as good at conveying what ails us as humans and yet presenting it in a way that makes us ok with our imperfect status.

An immediate all-time favorite.

This movies is brilliantly written by director Wes Anderson, and this is arguably his best film yet. Starring many famous actors and actresses (and new actors) such as Bill Murray, Bruce Willis, Ed Norton, Jared Gilman, Kara Hayward, Frances McDormand, and Tilda Swinton. This movie will make you laugh and cry at the same time. Check it out it is definitely worth it!!!

***This review contains spoilers***

I have to admit that I hadn't seen any Wes Anderson films until two or three years ago and Moonrise Kingdom is the first that I have had the pleasure of seeing in the theater.

My first Anderson experience was Bottle Rocket, and it didn't strike me as remarkable the first time I saw it. However, I found myself thinking about it over the next few days and ended up buying the Criterion Blu-ray.

I think there are a couple of important things to understand about Anderson's films:

The first is the level of detail. It's an assault on the brain and I've come to appreciate subsequent viewings more than with most films. Many lesser comedies fall flat because they run out of ideas and end up repeating them until they approach 90 minutes. Anderson's films have so many ideas it's ridiculous, but five of his seven films are also over by the 94-minute mark. The difference is that they are crammed with ideas and feel fresh and original.

The other major thing to note is the brand of humor. Call it offbeat or quirky, or whatever you like, but it's certainly distinctive. It's the type of humor that uses a phrase or situation which is familiar to you, but surprises you by giving it a different meaning. Think of Police Squad, Naked Gun, or Monty Python, and you'll understand what I mean. Like David Lynch, I think Anderson's mind makes unusual connections that most are incapable of. In order to appreciate his films, you need to investigate all of his worlds and understand the way that he thinks. It might be too much work for the casual viewer.

Let's get to Moonrise Kingdom.

The film is set in the 1960s on a small island off New England. It evokes a sense of nostalgia that's present throughout. This is a time in which cell phones and most electronic entertainment didn't exist. Take a look at the primitive record player for example. The story focuses on the budding romance between Sam (Gilman) and Suzy (Hayward). Sam is a scout and invites Suzy to run away with him, causing the small town to send out a search party.

The supporting cast includes some big names and a few Anderson favorites. The local cop is played by Bruce Willis and he's particularly effective in the role. The Scout Master is played by Edward Norton, who has an exaggerated sense of his own importance. He provides a lot of the humor in the few scenes he is in. Look out for the homage to The Shawshank Redemption when he discovers that Sam is missing.

Frances McDormand and Bill Murray play a married couple and both are lawyers. Jason Schwartzman's appearance is brief, but he makes good use of the time. One of my favorite characters is played by Tilda Swinton, and she is simply referred to as Social Services. Even Bob Balaban's narration is funny. It's hard to go into any more detail without ruining the entire plot, such as it is, so I'll stop there.

I mentioned that Anderson's films require several viewings to take in all the details, but I have to say that Moonrise Kingdom had an immediate impact on me. This is my style of humor and it felt like a Coen brothers movie, such as Burn After Reading, at times. Nothing much happens, but it's the style that's important. If you like Anderson's other films, you will almost certainly appreciate this.

I sometimes wonder what kind of childhood Anderson had. Are these characters based on his own experiences? Most are intelligent and suffered something of a troubled upbringing. When I think of Sam, or Max (from Rushmore), am I seeing the way Anderson views his own early life? Dysfunctional families are a favorite topic of his and Moonrise Kingdom is filled with them. Perhaps I had such an immediate connection to the film because it felt familiar after seeing his other work?

I'll close by saying that Anderson's films won't have universal or even large appeal, but if you appreciate his quirky style, you might just end up loving everything he does. I know that's true for me. I'll always remember that I first watched the film on my 50th birthday with two friends I have known since I was 11. That was a great experience and I would like to watch Moonrise Kingdom again right now.

Overall score 4.5/5 (with the potential to rise to 5/5 after repeat viewings).

Set in 1965, Moonrise Kingdom is a stylized coming of age film that delivers on its promise to bring the viewer of any age back to the intensity of just-entering-adolescence love. That alone makes this an extraordinary film. In addition, the music and imagery are beautifully orchestrated to delight the senses. The casting, characters, and acting are superb. It is rare to have a film that puts together this much talent and then taps it to the fullest.

Heavy hitters include the brilliant Edward Norton (for once watching his language and holding his temper) as an anal but dedicated troop leader, Bill Murray who in stark contrast to the young stars in this film, fails to find any joy whatsoever in his work in the law profession, wealth, family or beautiful surroundings. His dissatisfied wife (Frances McDormand who was the psychiatrist in Norton's first film Primal Fear), is also an attorney (the lawyer banter are some of the funniest lines in the film). Bruce Willis (who plays very well with child stars as he has a bit of child still left in him) is the bachelor, island cop who goes head-to-head with the chilling Tilda Swinton (white witch from Narnia) known only as "Social Services," as she callously plans to put "the boy" in juvenile refuge to undergo shock therapy as needed.

Despite the exceptionally strong adult cast, the two main child stars Sam and Suzy not only keep pace, but outshine the grownups with their unfailing loyalty and unconditional love for each other, both express an unthinking complete giving of themselves to one other. The film captures beautifully in the persons of these two intriguing social outcasts the experience of moving from being trapped in isolation into discovering and developing a union with another. I love how the two of them are so adult and wise in one way and still very much children, with childlike reasoning and priorities, e.g., Suzy runs away and packs a suitcase full of books and her kitten but not a change of clothes.

The cast is rounded out by a boyscout troop with scouts having inappropriately derogatory names as we did in my youth - such as lazy eye for the boy with the eyepatch. Also true to life was how dangerous and unsupervised our childhoods were then. Seeing the boy jump from two story height onto a trampoline without a surrounding net or a single spotter in sight, for example, really brought me back. And interactions with our parents really were pretty much restricted to being called to the table for dinner. I loved seeing Suzy's little brothers (Irish triplets) while away the time with all of the board and other none electronic games, fueled by a couple of dice or imagination.

Wes Anderson spins a simple, sweet story - yet the viewer never knows exactly where it is headed. Throughout, the film is subtly hilarious. In trademark Anderson fashion, the lines are delivered in an almost deadpan way with all the characters completely oblivious to the irony and ridiculousness of the situation, dialog, and even their lives and themselves. I highly recommend purchasing this movie; it's one you'll want to watch again and again and share with other people. I've already seen it four times and it hasn't even opened in theaters in my state, yet.

It's 1965, and this mystical-magical story will tug at the heartstrings as it entertains with delight for the entire family. Sam and Suzy are both age twelve, neither one of them is popular and they both have their own issues outside of their charming relationship. However, they are appealing to each other in a unique friendship when they decide to run away together in their own great adventure. Bruce Willis can play the role of just about anything, and in this captivating story, his acting performance is excellent, along with all the other characters. The heart-warming story is touching, enjoyable from start to finish, and very funny. A Magnificent fun-filled movie for the entire family. Highly Recommended!

Set in the 1960s, two twelve-years-olds Sam (played by Jared Gilman) and Suzy (played by Kara Hayward) meet and exchange letters that lead to Sam running away from scout camp and Suzy leaving home to meet him. Since the story takes place on an island, they can only hide for so long. The scout master (played by Edward Norton) enlists his scout troop to help him search for Sam and Suzy's family calls in the local island cop (played by Bruce Willis) to look for Suzy. They soon learn that the two are together. As a killer storm approaches the island, friendships and loyalties change.

This movie is special. There's humor, budding romance, tension and a great cast. The ending ties up all the loose ends in a practical, satisfying way.

It can probably go on record that Wes Anderson has never made a bad film. Certainly some are better than others and everyone is going to have their favorite(s) that they connect to the most (cough "Rushmore" cough cough), but his films are always enjoyable. It's hard to believe that "Moonrise Kingdom" is Anderson's first live-action film in five years and it may be his most well-rounded and personal film to date.

The film begins with a tour of the Bishop house, which is extraordinary. The camera pans from room to room as you're introduced to what seems like a life-sized dollhouse. The score of the film also enters the picture through Suzy's brother, Lionel's (Jake Ryan), battery operated record player. It's like a narrated introduction to the different types of instruments used in a full orchestra including harps, cellos, flutes, piccolos, electric and acoustic guitars, ukuleles, banjos, woodblocks, organs, and pianos among several other instruments. The score practically encompasses your senses and is very eclectic; the type of score that sticks to you like glue.

One of the first scenes in the film is the "flew the coop" scene. Any movie that references "The Shawshank Redemption" in its opening moments should already be on your radar of greatness. Anderson is also able to create these magnificent plays within his films. "Rushmore" had several and "Moonrise Kingdom" has the Noah's Ark play where Sam meets Suzy for the first time. If schools were ever able to put on plays like this regularly, their audience would only expand over time. They're just so creative.

The dancing scene on the beach is perhaps the one that has the most impact. Not only does it provide humor, but it's the first scene that really shows how far Sam and Suzy's relationship has actually escalated. The entire beach scene is just great anyway. It's not often that something of that length can be touching, memorable, and hilarious all at the same time. Only Wes Anderson can pull off something like that.

"Moonrise Kingdom" has all of Wes Anderson's trademarks including eye-catching cinematography, a fantastic score, intelligent humor, and an incredible cast. Many believe that this is Anderson's best work to date. The comedy-drama is certainly a welcome change of pace during a summer filled with blockbuster action and extravagant special effects. Although Bill Murray throws his shoe at Edward Norton and it's one of the best moments in cinema for the entire year. For once, "leaving your brain at the door," doesn't really apply here. "Moonrise Kingdom" is the type of movie that is charming for the soul and makes your brain happy in the process. All in all, it's just a heartfelt and well-written experience that will appeal to everyone.
Love it
Not the best Anderson. VERY quirky (as always). Great cast.
Melancholy story with the intrusion of reality into an ideal fantasy and a nice ending.
gift
My current favorite Wes Anderson movie.
The product is really great! The seller is really great too! Keep up the great work! Don't change a thing.
Love this movie
Great cast that does translate into a funny, charming movie.
Fantastic flick, Wes Anderson, always well done, always entertaining.
fun and interesting movie.  I'm a fan of the director.  this is one of my favorites of his.  the blu-ray disc technically is good also.
